SPEECH.PARA: Senator FAULKNER (New South Wales—Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (12.32 p.m.)—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. Let me address the committee on the matter that Senator Kernot raises. In fact, I think it might be useful for me to outline what the opposition's approach will be to the remainder of the committee stage debate on the bill.

I advise the committee that I will not be proceeding with opposition amendments (7) to (15) standing in the name of the opposition. The opposition will not be moving any further amendments to the bill and will not be supporting any of the amendments that have been proposed by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

As you would be aware, Mr Temporary Chairman, last Friday the Senate dealt with opposition amendments (5) and (6) to the work for the dole bill and, in our view, those two amendments were the critical amendments to the bill. They would have turned the work for the dole proposal into a decent labour market program. They sought to restrict the secretary's power to approve a program of work for unemployment payment so that the secretary could approve such a program only if: participants in the program did not displace existing workers; participants were paid for the hours they worked at the relevant award rate; participants were provided with accredited on‐ or off‐the‐job training; participants were able to leave the program to take up education training or employment opportunities without penalties; the people running the program were funded to cover any costs associated with supervision, materials, workers compensation, essential clothing, equipment and so on; and the program ran for at least six months. We believe that the work for the dole program is sensible only if it provides guarantees to existing Australian workers that their jobs are safe and if it provides participants with those benefits, especially access to training.

We want to make sure that the focus stays fairly and squarely on this government and on the jobs crisis that it has created in this country. In one month, in Australia, 40,000 jobs have just disappeared. Unemployment has shot up from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent since this government took office. There are now 57,400 fewer full‐time jobs in Australia than at the time of the Howard government's first budget in August 1996, and nearly 50,000 fewer than in January 1997. Yet the government obviously thinks that it can deflect the public's mind from this crisis with a program of some 10,000 places in a work for the dole scheme. These are 10,000 places in a scheme with no training, and they will not even make up for the jobs this government has just destroyed in a week.

Labor's amendments, as moved in committee on Friday, were the only amendments—and I stress that: they were the only amendments—which would have actually moved the government's work for the dole scheme in the direction of Tony Blair's welfare to work program. In recent days, both the government and the Democrats have said that they support Tony Blair's approach, which of course is fundamentally different from the work for the dole scheme in that it gives the unemployed various options, including education and training. But the government and the Democrats have voted against it.

We do agree with the government on certain aspects of the work for the dole program. As senators would be aware, we agree that it is not a training program, we agree that it does nothing to address structural problems—which, of course, have led to high unemployment—and we agree that it does not create a single real job. They are the government's words. Let me stress: we agree with them. But we do not, and we never will, buy the government's arguments that this program is about improving unemployed people's self‐esteem and their work ethic. There is absolutely no evidence in Australia or anywhere else to support the government's proposition. In fact, there is evidence to the contrary: that programs of this kind will actually harm the unemployed people they are supposed to help. The program may lower a person's self‐esteem, demoralise them, stigmatise them and make it even more difficult for them to obtain the real work that they need.

Let me summarise the situation, as I have been invited to do, that is before the committee at the moment. Let me also summarise the arguments that were developed in committee last Friday. Senator Kernot said that, if a sunset clause were to be inserted in the legislation, the Australian Democrats would not support opposition amendments Nos 5 and 6. The Senate did vote to insert a 24‐month sunset clause, and the Australian Democrats did not support our amendments. Senator Harradine certainly voted for our amendments. Senator Colston, despite all the rhetoric and, of course, being the coward that he is, voted against these amendments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You will have to withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw that, Mr Temporary Chairman. Clearly, the Australian Democrats are not committed to providing unemployed Australians with a decent chance of getting a job.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training say on the AM radio program this morning that the actions of the Senate will delay the commencement of the program. I want to make this absolutely clear to Dr Kemp and absolutely clear to the government and to the public of Australia: Dr Kemp and everyone else really knows that the government's work for the dole program could start tomorrow. There are no impediments to the work for the dole program starting tomorrow. The government does not need to pass anything in this bill before the program can start. But Dr Kemp is saying, `Let the government get on with it.' The Labor Party, in these circumstances, says to Dr Kemp and the government, `Get on with it. Don't use Senate obstructionism as an excuse because there is none and there never has been any.'

Let it be on the government's head when the work for the dole program fails, and fails miserably, and when our young unemployed Australians become even more despairing of ever finding a job. It will be on Dr Kemp's and the government's heads when that occurs. That does outline, as I have been requested to do, the approach that the opposition will be taking during the remainder of the committee stage. I commend that approach to the committee.

I want to address some comments Senator Faulkner made. There has been a significant shift in the Labor Party's position over the weekend. We all know why that is so, and it has got nothing to do with the fact that a sunset clause was passed. It has got everything to do with the fact that there is not a lot of community understanding out there that this bill, as it now stands, can apply the principle of work for the dole to most unemployed Australians. I think Senator Faulkner's comments really show us that the rhetoric about Senate obstructionism is a matter of some concern to them—as it is to us. I think it has been totally misrepresented by Minister Kemp in this and other debates.

Senator Faulkner said there were two critical amendments. There are two that I have chosen as being critical. Firstly, the sunset clause. I repeat that is a critical amendment because the bill as it stands does not reflect what the Prime Minister told Australia he wanted to implement. He said, `We are going to implement a pilot program for 10,000 young unemployed Australians.' In fact, this bill applies the principle of work for the dole to nearly all unemployed Australians some time in the future, whenever the government wishes.

We do not think that that is appropriate. There are competing principles here. On the airwaves in the last 24 hours the minister has talked about `All we are seeking to do is to apply the principle of work for the dole.' Yes, but this government is seeking to apply that principle without further parliamentary scrutiny when they choose to extend that principle to those who were not part of the Prime Minister's announcement.

I think the minister said on Friday, `We want to extend the principle and we do not want to come back.' Yes, you want to extend the principle of work for the dole from 10,000 young, unemployed Australians to whomever you see fit in the future, and the competing principle is that it is surely inappropriate to do that without further parliamentary debate upon an evaluation of the scheme.

I see those as the two crucial amendments. First, you cannot implement a scheme that you can apply as you see fit without any further parliamentary debate and scrutiny and, the second was the principle of compulsion versus voluntarism. Labor does not want to test the notion of compulsion any more; the Democrats do. That is why I have moved these amendments.

We firmly believe that if the government had given young people a choice of options and less of a stick than loss of total benefits—something more in line with the Tony Blair four options plan with loss of 40 per cent of benefit at the end if young people fail to cooperate and find an option that works for them—that would have been something much easier to vote for.

But this is a miserable, one‐off, non‐negotiable option, the details of which are not even clear to this parliament before we are asked to put in place the big picture, the principle, that we are being asked to vote on. That is why we would like to test the matter. The Labor Party's rhetoric up until this moment has been: `We are opposed to the notion of compulsion.' I do not think the explanation that is being given—that the Senate would not agree to make these labour market programs—helps the Labor Party slide out from why they have walked away from their opposition to compulsion.

I will not belabour the point, because we are all acutely aware of the rhetorical battle and the misrepresentation that is going on out there in the wider community on this point. But on a point of principle that is why I have moved Democrat amendments Nos 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10, which oppose the notion of compulsion.

I am happy to make another intervention in the debate. I will try to make it as clear as I can for you, and I am sure that you will understand the position the opposition is taking.

SPEECH.PARA: I did inform the Senate a little earlier, Senator Brown, that the Labor Party would not be voting for these amendments that are currently before the chair or for any other amendments to the bill, due to the failure of others in the Senate to support our crucial amendments 5 and 6 in the debate that took place in the committee on Friday. I do ac knowledge, Senator Brown, that you supported those amendments.

The Labor Party has made it clear from the outset in this debate that the government's work for the dole scheme is a punitive, mickey mouse scheme that will do nothing to address Australia's high and rising level of unemployment, including of course the rate of youth unemployment. On Friday in this chamber I moved detailed amendments which would have built improvements and protections into the scheme and would have transformed the scheme into something positive. But the failure of the government and the Australian Democrats to support these crucial amendments makes it impossible to improve this scheme into the skills training and labour market program that Australia's young unemployed now so desperately need.

The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, and others on the Labor side made it very clear early in this debate that we would be presenting a clear and a better alternative to the work for the dole scheme, and that if the government did not accept that alternative then it would have to wear the consequences of a flawed scheme.

The consequences of the work for the dole scheme are that Australia's unemployment will get worse; it won't get better. So on Friday in the committee stage I moved an amendment to require that this bill not allow any project to proceed unless there be a legal requirement that the scheme will not cause persons in employment to lose their employment.

I also said in the debate on Friday, as senators would recall, that this clause was crucial, based on overseas experience. In the United States, work for the dole programs have pushed thousands of paid workers out of jobs; laws have needed to be passed to prevent displacement of paid workers.

There are widespread and escalating concerns about job security amongst workers in this country right now. The last thing that Australian workers need is more insecurity about their jobs. Yet, of course, we had a situation where government senators and others voted against our amendment to protect job security. Senator Kernot does not like this, but the Australian Democrat senators voted against it too, as you would recall. So, so much for any highfaluting concerns about jobs and job security. Numerous community groups made it very clear to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee that this scheme would not be of any use unless it had accredited training opportunities built into it. The amendments that I moved on Friday sought to make that happen too. But again, the government and the Democrats have prevented this from occurring by voting the amendments down.

The government has been using the work for the dole bill to try to divert attention from its abject failure to reduce unemployment in Australia. It has been trying to take public pressure off itself to generate jobs and turn the public pressure on to the unemployed, to blame them for not being able to get work. That has been the government's strategy. What we in the Labor Party say is that we will not allow it to succeed in that strategy. The Labor Party will not allow the government to manipulate the prejudices which exist in the community against unemployed people into a debate about compulsion or non‐compulsion to work. Senator Kernot invites me to make some comments about compulsion, so let me do so.

The amendments that I moved here on Friday were to give unemployed people options for training and skills development as part of the requirements on them to receive unemployment payments. The main issue in dispute between the Labor Party and the government is therefore not compulsion itself, but the value and quality of the programs in which the unemployed are required to participate. The failure of the Senate to improve the quality of the program, in our view, makes it absolutely pointless for us to proceed further with these amendments. By not supporting further amendments, we will be ensuring that jobs is the issue in the future—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be ensuring that jobs is the issue at the next election too, Senator Kernot, not blaming those people who cannot get jobs. What we in the Labor Party intend to do is make the government pay for its failure to improve employment in this country.

It is possible, of course, at the end of this debate, for any party to look to see whether the Social Security (Work for the Dole) Bill is supportable or not and then vote for or against the bill. And there could be efforts made at the moment to gain support for that. But, looking around the Senate, because it is a poll driven debate, for all the fine words that are mentioned here, people are putting their fingers up and seeing which way the wind is blowing in relation to the populist talkback radio and the tabloid response, which is often very misleading. SPEECH.PARA: It is possible to vote against the bill. I certainly have not seen anything in this bill which would allow me to support the bill, but as I look around this chamber I am not sure that other people are not putting their fingers up in the air to find out which way the wind is blowing. It is not good enough that this is the way the Senate responsibility is taken.

We have heard a lot about scapegoat politics in the last few weeks. It is about finding a victim and blaming the victim. It is also about standing back while other people do that, albeit successfully, as a populist cause. I will quote from Martin Niemoeller, a German theologian who lived from 1892 to 1984:

When Hitler attacked the Jews I was not a Jew, therefore, I was not concerned. And when Hitler attacked the Catholics, I was not a Catholic, and therefore, I was not concerned. And when Hitler attacked the unions and the industrialists, I was not a member of the unions and I was not concerned. Then, Hitler attacked me and the Protestant church—and there was nobody left to be concerned.

I wonder how many people in this populist response to unemployment, to blaming the victim in Australia, are doing it because they themselves are not unemployed; they themselves do not know how difficult it is and how demeaning it is and how little opportunities there are and that the government are not helping in their response in all different sorts of ways.

I would like you to know that there are people in the community who will stand up, no matter what that wind is doing, no matter what that populist, knee‐jerk, scapegoat response will be. I do think it is disgraceful for people to take a knee‐jerk response now. The Greens will be continuing to try to improve this bill, knowing that there is not the guts in this chamber to stand up for what is right and what is wrong. We will be continuing to try to improve it because we know there are not the numbers there to have the courage to oppose a bad and wicked bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go back to the arguments about compulsion versus voluntarism and preface my remarks with the observation I made on Friday that it is so interesting the way the Liberal Party hates compulsory voting but loves to compel young unemployed people to work for the dole. The bill talks a lot about mutual obligation and the Labor Party has an amendment which uses the term `reciprocal obligation'. The notion of mutual obligation underpinning the provision of income support is a shift and I think most people identify that.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to shift, then a reciprocal obligation must surely be the way to go. It is one thing to compel young people to turn up and put in some hours, hopefully in some work experience, but it is another thing for the government to say that it has no reciprocal obligations—that is, to provide training and to provide a job at the end of the so-called work experience.

I think that it is dishonest to make a big point about mutual obligations and to absolve the government from any longer term meaningful responsibility for young unemployed Australians—for all unemployed Australians. The government has an obligation. It has a reciprocal obligation. That obligation involves meaningful training and job creation. The bill requires young people to turn up for 2½ days a week where, in the best circumstances, they might get some training. I acknowledge that local councils have said that they may have the capacity to provide some meaningful training, but a lot of other groups have said they do not and therefore are wary of being involved.

In my view, the important point about compulsion is the message it sends. It says to all of us, `It is not the government's problem. It is your problem that you are unemployed; therefore you have to take the responsibility rather than the government taking the longer term responsibility.' I will read from the Senate committee hearings what I think are some pertinent comments from people who have experience in this field—probably a lot more than we do. The leaders of four of Australia's Christian churches stated:

The notion of mutual obligation between young people and society is damaged by the compulsory nature of this scheme. We the community also have an obligation to provide training, jobs, as soon as possible, and a minimum payment to survive. The compulsion threatens to undermine voluntary work, it risks deploying youth as cheap labour and it has the debilitating image of earning handouts.

I know that there are arguments you can mount against that. It does send a strong message that you blame the victim and do not take any further responsibility. The Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition stated:
Compulsory schemes marginalise the unemployed, tell prospective employers nothing about a young person's enthusiasm for work; they ignore existing skills and create no real or lasting jobs.

However you want to look at it, unfortunately these are some of the deficiencies in the way this scheme is designed. I have said so many times that if it had been better designed I think we would have found it easier to support it. The last piece of evidence I want to quote is from the Brotherhood of St Laurence's witness, Ms Macdonald. She stated:

The government's program represents and promotes the belief that unemployment is a problem because of deficiencies in individuals, like being unmotivated or lacking a work ethic, rather than recognising that there is insufficient demand or growth in the economy to employ all of those who want to work.

That is the reality. But we all know about the populism attached to this issue. The community out there thinks that all we are doing today is putting in place a pilot program for 10,000 young unemployed Australians. We are not doing that. I do not have second thoughts that we could expect 10,000 young Australians to volunteer—whether they would be in all the right areas is another matter. Until the design is better and until there are better safeguards and guarantees we should not pretend, firstly, that this bill can do what it may not do and, secondly, that it applies only to young unemployed Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did. They agreed to the sunset clause.

—Senator Kernot, the sunset clause is subsidiary to this. It does not bring in a skills component. What I am saying to you is that, because Labor is insisting on a skills component, you ought not give up on getting rid of the compulsion. And I say to Senator Faulkner: because you are insisting on a compulsion component, you ought not give up on insisting there be skills training built into this scheme. I want you to think again.

SPEECH.PARA: It is too important to dismiss without further consultation. It is going to take some time but it very rapidly can be fixed. Let us get back to where we were last week. Because I feel so strongly about this—because the Greens feel so strongly about this—I make an appeal to both of you to stick by the arguments that you put last week and to think of the people who are going to be affected by this move.

Senator Faulkner, I cannot accept the argument that we should let this go because it is going to worsen unemployment and the government is going to suffer as a result. We have to think about the unemployed people themselves. We have to act in their interests. I say to you and Senator Kernot: for goodness sake, get together and fix this. Let us get this back on track. Let us not allow the government to run between the two of you and get everything it wants because there was a disagreement about whether the skills component or the compulsion component was the most or least important. Therefore, to enable you to do that, I move:
That the committee report progress and have leave to sit again.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have here is a double backflip with compulsion, but without skill. That is how the work training scheme will go through here. It will be compulsory, just as the government wanted, and it will be without skills training, just as the government wanted, all because the two major parties on this side of the chamber who believe both components should be altered cannot agree on which one is the more important. That is how I see it.

SPEECH.PARA: I know there will be arguments from the Democrats that there is not built into this the financial wherewithal for skills. I know Labor will argue that it is the government's mess and we should leave them to pick up the fallout further down the line. But those things ought not be countenanced. It was up to us to remedy the situation. Anybody later reading this argument and this legislation's passage through the Senate will pick up that both the Labor Party and the Democrats failed to get through what they wanted because they split on the emphasis.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot says that is not true, but it is true. The Democrats' failure to support Labor amendments last week is leading to the Labor failure to support Democrat amendments this week.
—No, it's not. It's the politics of the double dissolution that's causing Labor to change their mind. Everybody knows that.

—Senator Kernot can argue that it is the politics of the double dissolution, but I argue that it is politics per se that is going to see this government scheme get through and the work for the dole scheme made compulsory and without a skills training component being implemented. That is the thin end of the wedge, to say the least.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not anyone in this place who will pay the penalty. It will be a dispossessed, disempowered, very often depressed and pessimistic group of mostly young Australians who will be picked out to pay the price of what is happening here today. That is not good enough. It is a real pity. It should not be happening this way. I will leave Senator Kernot to argue, as she will, about Labor's political motivation on this issue. What we had to practice in here was a better form of political cooperation on an issue like this where the numbers are on this side of the Senate but the government is going to win anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I want to give the Senate an explanation of exactly where we are in relation to these amendments that are before the committee at the moment. Senator Kernot has moved amendments Nos 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10. Amendments Nos 7, 8, 9 and 10 would have the effect of negating what is contained in the bill. We will be separating them and dealing with them separately when it comes to the vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. That saves me from doing the same thing. I am a bit bemused by all of this. We are dealing with amendments moved by Senator Kernot, concerning matters about which there was a lot of debate on Friday last week. I am disappointed that they were defeated. I am greatly disappointed. Nevertheless, it generally falls to the committee process to improve the legislation as best we can. At the end of the day, if we do not like it, we then vote against the third reading.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be most unfortunate if the Senate did not give a very clear message to the government as to what it thinks about compulsion versus non‐compulsion. We have the opportunity to do this with this particular amendment. I think it would be unfortunate, to say the least, if the opposition did not see it that way as well. I think the opposition has an enormous opportunity at the present moment to register its views about this particular question of compulsion versus non-compulsion. If, at the end of the day, they do not like the bill anyhow, they can vote against it. That is my prerogative as well. But let us give the government and the people of Australia an indication as to what we think.

The government says that it is reinforcing the principle, as it sees it, of mutual obligation. The government is saying that these obligations go to a proposition that they say is fair and reasonable, that persons in receipt of the dole payments should have to work for the dole; in other words, that unemployed people should sing for their supper. The government believes that it is fair and reasonable that people receiving unemployment allowances from the community should be required to make a contribution in return.

A number of questions arise from that, including whether the measure applies to all recipients of the dole or just the 10,000 unemployed people between the ages of 18 and 24. The question arises whether it is fair that one group be singled out in this way. These are debates that have gone to and fro, but it is essential that we look at this question again when considering this particular measure.

On the other side, on the non-compulsory side, one has to realise, and the committee needs to realise, that unemployment benefit is in fact a right. If unemployment benefit is, in economic terms, a transfer of payment resulting from the government's and the community's failure to provide employment, should such a payment create an obligation on the part of the recipient of that payment? Should unemployed people be made to feel guilty about not being able to get a job? Should they be made to feel guilty about receiving what is a perfectly legitimate payment by being forced to undertake tasks which have no prospect of leading to meaningful employment in that particular area?

The other question that does arise—and this has been debated in the public arena—is: what impact does compulsion have on a person's self-esteem? In relation to compulsion, I will refer to a submission made by the Salvation Army to the Senate committee. Again, I would like to say that I am indebted to the Senate committee for its work on this particular matter. Whilst I am on my feet, I would also like to pay tribute to those Senate officers who prepare running sheets. I do very much appreciate it when they are provided to the committee. But the Salvation Army says:

We do not believe that forcing people to accept unsuitable options has any benefit to the individual, the project activity or indeed other participants on the same program. Our experience has shown that it is preferable to promote the positive aspect of participation rather than simply compel people to attend. As a result of discussions with our staff with experience in other parts of the world, we have concluded that compulsion is a sure way to ensure that such a scheme does not work.

So that is a very telling response from the Salvation Army. In any event, I believe compulsion would probably be unnecessary to sell to those unemployed persons a scheme for them to be able to participate in. Is the government saying that most would not want to participate and, therefore, it needs to be compulsory for the program to operate? Certainly the government's proposal in the bill appears to insinuate that the unemployed do not want to work. I am sure that is not the government's view, but that is what sort of message is coming though the legislation.

Obviously the question of unintended consequences has been canvassed in another sphere, but I think it is desirable for the committee to amend the bill. Even though the bill will still be imperfect, it will not be as imperfect as it would have been if we had allowed this particular clause to stay as it is. That is what our job as a committee is—to attempt to improve where we can. Then in the final analysis, if we do not like it, we can vote against the third reading of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal with some of the comments Senator Brown made. On Friday, the Labor Party supported the Democrat amendment to insert a sunset clause. At no stage did they say, `If this gets through and you don't support our labour market amendments, we are going to walk away from compulsion.' We came to this debate this morning expecting to continue on that line. The Labor Party have changed their minds on that. I think, despite what you say about us disagreeing, the fact of the matter is that it is politics. That is the reason. It is not a lack of formal agreement between us or a falling out between us. It is just the way this has worked out.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of a sunset clause and compulsion, we are not walking away from our desire to remove the compulsory aspect of this bill. We are going to put those amendments. We are going to call a division on those amendments. On the matter of the labour market programs, I wonder if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is able to give us any indication of what those extensive amendments may have cost.

BREAK.PARA: I have said all along that I think skills, training and a job outcome were very important. I have also acknowledged that, if this were a real pilot program for 10,000 young unemployed, I think you would get mostly volunteers and, also, you would get some schemes that worked. I was prepared to extend to the government one opportunity to put in place the trial that they set, with some safeguards, and an opportunity for all of us to evaluate it so that they could not extend it, at whim, to all unemployed Australians. I do not think that is an unfair position to have to argue. It is the Labor Party that has changed its mind today. We know that and the vote will reflect that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In direct response to Senator Kernot—who raised during the last division the question of the cost of the Labor Party's amendments on labour market programs—I am advised that the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs does not have a costing on those amendments, except the advice is that they would be very expensive. In that context, I point out that in the new work opportunities program, which was in the last year of the Labor government, there was a four per cent success rate and a net cost of $143,000 per job. That may give Senator Kernot some idea of the sorts of costs that Labor has been prepared to see in the past in terms of these kinds of programs.

SPEECH.PARA: That is certainly not the direction in which this government is prepared to go. It is not simply a question of cost. We believe that the money that is available from measures such as Working Nation is more appropriately put to helping individuals, as effectively as we can, try to prepare themselves to obtain work. For that, it might be that somebody needs to get the skills for work that is available in their locality. It might be that they have English language problems or literacy problems. But we feel that the money that is available is much better spent on a more flexible system than we have had in the past that goes to the real needs of individuals in the community in which they are looking for work.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that the new program, which Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp have been working on, is much more likely to contribute to good outcomes than something like that new work opportunities program, which produced only a four per cent success rate. This, of course, is not a labour market program. We have always said it is—and we do not make an apology for it—an initiative with a very specific purpose, because we believe it will lift the self‐esteem of young Australians. New jobs—real jobs—come by other means, and that was referred to in the second reading speech. I do not want to replace the program.

Let me deny utterly Senator Margetts's claim that this is all about blaming the victim. We believe that some of the most serious victims of the last government's economic management are those young people who have left school with inadequate skills, have become long‐term unemployed and have now lost their self‐esteem. While the total program is not geared solely to those who have so lost their self‐esteem that they will not come forward to volunteer their service to their community, there is a substantial and often hidden element about whom that is the truth—that they have lost all confidence in their abilities. We want to help them particularly, and that is one of the reasons why we think the compulsory element has real virtue.

There is no question of blaming the victim. It is a matter of helping those who have become victims because of the recession that, if you like, we had to have—youngsters who left school and found that, while there might have been a short‐term job, there was no long‐term job because they did not have the skills to keep it or to find another one. We are very serious about trying to help these young people of 18 to 24. It is very appropriate that we first have pilot programs and evaluate very carefully how they succeed. With the evaluation process, it is important to take a compulsory element into account as well as a voluntary one, and in some communities there will need to be a mix of both. The concept of mutual obligation between the community and the unemployed is a very important aspect of this scheme. Under this concept, it is fair and just that people be asked to contribute to the community in return for their unemployment payment.

It does not apply only to those who wish to work for payment. It should apply to everyone. If one group of young unemployed volunteers to participate in the scheme, it is only fair that others in similar circumstances be asked to participate. Those who do not volunteer to participate in the scheme are likely to gain the most from an increase in self‐esteem, a stronger work ethic and the social contacts that they would develop while on the scheme. If the pilot projects were to rely solely on volunteers, there may be insufficient people in some places to fill the available spots. We need the option of being able to refer people to projects where there are vacancies. It is a pilot scheme, and in order to evaluate its success we need to be able to compare different models.

In any case, the arrangements in that sense about compulsion are similar to those that existed under Labor's labour market programs where participants were required to participate as part of the activity test or their activity agreement. Some young unemployed 18‐ to 24‐year‐olds—for example, those with very low self‐esteem—may lack the confidence. To compel them to participate may be the only practical way to demonstrate to them that they can make a real contribution to the community, thereby improving their confidence and work skills.

But we do say that, as a government, we want to give the potential sponsors—the community organisations—as much flexibility as possible, and sponsors who have some reservation about compulsion will be able to put forward proposals which are for 100 per cent voluntary programs as their first choice. But there is no guarantee that there will be sufficient volunteers available for any one project, and the government cannot enter into a contractual arrangement with a sponsor on that basis. Consequently, all potential work for the dole sponsors will have to sign a standard form of contract that will make provision for the referral of compulsorily referred potential participants where there are insufficient volunteers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. There are already examples in places like Walcha in New South Wales where there are telecottages enabling people to get access to an affordable range of skills, processing contracts employing up to 30 people at a time. In northern Victoria some 17 farming families have been able to get in touch with the Asian markets via e‐mail and establish a very live business in terms of marketing and selling vegetables to Asia. That has increased the profit per hectare by several hundred per cent in that region alone. It is an example of what can occur when you are plugged into the Net, when you are plugged into the telecommunications revolution. In Narembeen in Western Australia there is now a telecentre serving some 1,000 people which is looking at becoming involved with a pilot project in Western Australia for telemedicine.

So for the first time what we will see as a result of this fund is, I suspect, an enormous number of applications that will exceed the funds that are available over the five‐year period. It will enable communities to make applications—in conjunction, in some instances, with private sector enterprises. They will very much appreciate that this government understands the needs and appreciates what opportunities are available through the telecommunications revolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do I start? ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill, I believe, answered a question last week in respect of representation at the United Nations General Assembly meeting being held in New York. He has made the point very clear that he will be representing the Australian government. He intends to put Australia's position very clearly.

Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gases is about 1.4 per cent. As Senator Hill pointed out here a week or so ago, if you closed the whole of Australia down the impact on global CO2 emissions would be negligible. Notwithstanding that, we recognise the fact that there has been some human effect on CO2 emissions and we intend to address it in a fair and equitable way.

Australia is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention of Climate Change and to participating constructively in the Berlin man date negotiations. As Senator Hill has pointed out, we are committed to seeking an effective, equitable and realistic outcome at the Kyoto conference in December. The challenge is to arrive at an outcome which can serve as a basis for future rounds of climate change negotiations.

What is needed is a balanced approach and one that is in the interests of Australia. The outcome must be realistic and achievable to ensure an effective environmental outcome. It must be fair and equitable—a viewpoint that has been taken by a resolution put before the US Congress. Targets must not impose unequal costs on countries. The economic impact on each Australian should be the same as for each American, Canadian, European or Japanese. I might point out that the contribution to global greenhouse gases from a country like the United States is about 26 per cent compared to Australia's 1.4 per cent.

The outcome must be cost-effective. There must be flexibility to achieve emission reductions at least cost. The outcome must take account of individual circumstances for each country by ensuring differentiated country commitments. Australia firmly believes that a uniform target which ignores individual country circumstances would fail to address any one of those fundamental requirements.
In conclusion, I notice that the press release to which Senator Brown referred was put out by Clive Hamilton from the Australia Institute. Clive Hamilton and you, Senator Brown, are in good company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister representing the Minister for Finance to questions without notice asked by Senators Faulkner, Mackay and Lundy today, relating to information technology outsourcing proposals of the Department of Finance.

We have seen through question time today a very grudging confirmation from the Minister representing the Minister for Finance (Senator Kemp) about part of a very sorry tale which has emerged from the estimates committees over the past few weeks. It really is a tale of sloppy decision making, of careless manage ment of public funds. It is really more appropriate to the corporate cowboy era of the 1980s.

I think it is important at the outset of this important debate to lay the facts on the table about what has occurred. In February 1997, the Department of Veterans' Affairs let IT outsourcing to ISSC, which is a consortium headed by IBM. The contract was worth $65 million. On 6 March this year, ISSC—unsolicited—approached the Department of Finance and proposed that the department piggyback on the DVA contract and that Finance outsource its IT requirements using the expansion provisions of the DVA contract. On 18 March this year, there was advice to the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey). We found out that there was no written record of the 6 March meeting. There was no proposal in writing from ISSC. Shortly after 18 March, Minister Fahey gave his approval for continued contact with ISSC.

On 24 March 1997, a meeting initiated by DOF—involving DOF, OGIT and DVA—was held on the piggyback proposal. This was the first occasion on which the proposal was discussed with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In fact, when the Department of Veterans' Affairs first heard about ISSC's unsolicited approach, they asked them to stop. On 15 April there was a meeting of the DOF management board, which formally agreed to continued negotiations with ISSC. On 24 April, the minister gave directions concerning procurement. On 25 April, the Minister for Finance issued a press release called `Outsourcing of Finance IT infrastructure', referring to generating competition through multiple tenders.

On 2 May, there was the first written communication from ISSC to DOF on the piggyback proposal. That was eight days after the minister had given his direction. They received written communication from ISSC eight days after his direction. At the beginning of May, of course, the Minister for Finance made a decision that, after Finance, no further piggybacking would be allowed. What a sorry tale this is.

Officials have revealed at estimates hearings that at no time was it made clear to com panies who expressed an interest in bidding for the original DVA contract that the possibility existed for another department to be shoehorned into that contract. Apparently ISSC, alone among the potential bidders, sussed out the opportunity to grab the Department of Finance contract without any further competitive tendering at all. Without a second thought, without even consulting the Department of Veterans' Affairs, we had a situation where Finance and OGIT went straight to Minister Fahey with a recommendation that negotiations commence.

Did Mr Fahey ask any questions? No, not at all. Did Mr Fahey insist on seeking a formal written proposal from ISSC? No, he did not. No, he could hardly wait to give this proposition the tick. Forget about the other companies who might be better placed to bid for this business, and forget about the substantial differences between DOF's processing and DVA's. What matters to the government is to outsource, downsize, contract out, cut back—and to do it as quickly as possible and at any cost.

We say enough is enough. This proposal has been shonky from the start. It is not enough to say, `There will be no more piggybacking after Finance piggybacks on DVA.' There are many defects in this scheme, which have been acknowledged by the minister, grudgingly and tardily, in prescribing the piggyback practice. In our view, the minister should admit that this has been a shonk from the start and call a halt now to any further negotiations. I call on him to do that, and I call on the Auditor-General to be invited to investigate this incredible mess and to report to parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) talks about sloppy decision making. If he would care to go over the record of his party during its 13 years in government, I think the last thing he ought to be talking about is sloppy decision making, particularly in relation to this issue of IT outsourcing. I think it is probable that Senator Faulkner has forgotten that it was the Labor government, which he was a part of, that initiated IT outsourcing in 1991. It was not this government that started it. No, it was Senator Faulkner's government that started it in 1991. They were the ones who initiated IT outsourcing as long ago as that. In 1991—
—So what?
—Were they shonks?

—We never suggested that you were shonks, did we, in all of the things that you did? Can I tell you that in 1991 the Department of Veterans' Affairs entered into this five-year deal with Ferntree to outsource its mainframe.
—You are a shonk and a liar.
—Senator Faulkner, would you like to withdraw those comments, please?
—Is it unparliamentary to call somebody a shonk, Madam Deputy President?
—It was another word you added to it.
—Anything else in addition to shonk, I withdraw.

—We need to remember that in 1991 the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, issued an industry statement, when he was talking about building a competitive Australia, in which he established the contracting out of government IT work as Labor government policy. Those policies have been continued by this government when it comes to the contracting out of IT. Those opposite seem to have conveniently forgotten Mr Beazley's December 1995 Framework and strategies for information technology in the Commonwealth of Australia . That document reaffirmed the outsourcing of information technology as part of Labor government policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy President, Senator Faulkner raises the issue of the Department of Veterans' Affairs contract and suggests that it was a shonky deal. Can I just reaffirm to you that, with the issue relating to piggybacking, the approach to the department by ISSC to join the outsourcing contract with the Department of Veterans' Affairs was unsolicited. The Department of Finance's approach is consistent with the overall strategy for whole of government IT infrastructure outsourcing using the purchasing guidelines.

This option is merely being explored. The outcome is not a foregone conclusion and it remains subject to the demonstration of value for money. Making the process of negotiations, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) is trying to suggest, with the ISSC subject to ministerial direction before commencing negotiations was appropriate given the size of the project and the broader policy context of the whole of government IT outsourcing.

Then we go to the issue of the other tenderers' awareness of the capacity to piggyback. The purchasing guidelines issued by DAS allow for piggybacking, that is, the utilisation of an open tender conducted by another agency, rather than pursue a separate open tender, if there is a similarity of requirement. The Department of Veterans' Affairs contract and the request for tender included provision for significant growth for work load volumes—100 per cent growth in the services covered by the contract within the existing pricing structure.

Let me tell you that some of the issues that were raised in the Canberra Times article that has been referred to are an attack on the ethics of Finance officials; they are regrettable and they are without any foundation. Finance is operating entirely within the Commonwealth procurement guidelines, which state:
Agencies should ensure that costs incurred in promoting competition are commensurate with the benefits received.

That is entirely what is being done. We are making sure; decisions have not been made; the outcome is not a foregone conclusion; and it remains the subject of a demonstration of value for money, which is exactly what the procurement guidelines, which the department is operating under, state. The costs to the department of going to tender shortly after the DVA contract was signed were assessed as being substantial while the benefits were considered to be minimal at best, and it was considered most likely that the Commonwealth would incur significant costs on the other side of the ledger. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —In commenting on the same matter, I will start my contribution by reiterating what Senator Faulkner said. This is a shonk. It is a shonk—there is no other description for it. A DVA contract was put out to tender and, as a result of that, ISSC rang up the Department of Finance and said, `With regard to the DVA tender, we would not mind actually piggybacking on the DVA tender with regard to the Department of Finance.' They did not only just ring the Department of Finance; they rang a number of agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Senate estimates hearings that were referred to earlier, DVA indicated very clearly that they did not know anything about it. OGIT themselves said they did not know anything about it until the Department of Finance rang them and told them, and the Department of Finance did not know anything about it until they were contacted by ISSC.

What is going on here? Have ISSC got some kind of crystal ball, some sort of prescience of which we are unaware or some sort of prescience that other tenderers do not have? No, they do not. This is a shonk. The reason for this kind of coverage in the newspapers is that it is a shonk and it is indefensible.
While we are talking about those Senate estimates hearings, which Senator Lundy, Senator Faulkner and I sat through for hours and hours while attempting to get answers from the officials—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's only because you kept asking so many stupid questions.

—We did indeed ask a lot of questions, and we did not get any answers. In fact I will come to some of the answers that we got a bit later on. Let me actually read into the Hansard part of the Canberra Times article that has been referred to, because I think it pretty much epitomises the performance of the minister opposite with regard to these estimates. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The crass performance of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Rod Kemp, before the Senate hearings has enhanced his reputation as one of the Opposition's greatest assets.
He is certainly one of our greatest assets and he is one of the coalition's biggest liabilities.

BREAK.PARA: Let me come to the kinds of responses that we got when we raised some of these questions at the estimates hearings. I have got to say that it was the greatest show in town. It was an absolute joke. Senator Lundy asked a question about what the definition of `phased' was. For the Senate's illumination, there are two things we are talking about here. `Clean break' is when you actually pay people out; when you pay them what they are due, when you give them a redundancy payment; when you actually pay them out in relation to superannuation. `Phased' is a euphemism for basically doing over workers, transferring them from the public sector to the private sector with a subsequent diminution of benefit.

So, as for the costings, which we received after quite a bit of a hoo‐ha—and I might go into that a bit later if I have time—we were told that the savings the government projected as a result of this IT outsourcing initiative were close to a billion dollars. That was in the estimates, in the PBS. We asked how these calculations were determined. It was by the phased approach, apparently, we were told. We got that after adjourning the committee and emissaries were sent to the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) to establish whether it was okay to tell the Senate estimates committee how calculations that are publicly available were determined.

So we asked OGIT, `What is the definition of "phased"?' The response was: `We can't tell you that, Senator. That is cabinet‐in‐confidence.' So they had no definition of the methodology which was used to determine a financial saving of close to a billion dollars. They could not tell us what the definition of `phased' was, but Minister Fahey got up in the House of Representatives and said, `This is a fantastic initiative. This is going to save the government $1 billion.' But they could not even define what `phased' was.

Not only that; the approach that they are talking about was based on a model that was used in two hospitals at DVA and then extrapolated across the whole public sector. That is how they came up with the figure of a $960 million saving. What a joke! This whole thing has been a joke from beginning to end. It is characterised by ineptness and complete incompetence by the minister concerned. I repeat that it is a shonk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on answers given to questions without notice relating to the government's IT outsourcing policy. In the recent estimates hearings, we had many hours of tedious questioning by the senators opposite.
—It's only tedious when you don't like the answers.

—It just went on and on, Senator, going over exactly the same ground over and over again. What was achieved? Nothing very much. As my colleague Senator Ferguson and the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) said earlier, the previous government had committed itself to IT outsourcing. The Department of Veterans' Affairs are a classic example of that; their Ferntree contract went from 1992 through until this year, and has, in fact, been very successful and has saved money.
—Has it? Well, what did ANAO say about it?

—It has been successful. The new government decided to do further outsourcing with OGIT overseeing the whole issue. The government has decided on a policy of clustering its IT work—in other words, several departments together. That is government policy and what is going on now is a pilot in this direction.

SPEECH.PARA: The government went out and got a request for tender from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. All the tenderers knew, as my colleague Senator Ferguson said, that it was government policy to piggyback on open tenders. Everyone knew about that. All the tenderers also knew that the demands of the Department of Veterans' Affairs on IT were going down, not up, and that the contract was for an overrun of 100 per cent of the requirements of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. So there was a lot of room for the government to put an additional part in the cluster. That is exactly what happened. The tenderers knew that that was a possibility and that, in fact, is what happened.

BREAK.PARA: The Department of Finance made the decision that they would make use of that opportunity—it also fitted into a time slot between the two lots of budget work—to go ahead quickly to use the existing contract to achieve the savings earlier than otherwise would have been available. That is basically what has happened. The Australian government is saving money in this process. It has been through proper process and OGIT supported this process.

We are looking at a pilot of clustering of IT outsourcing. That is what it has really been about. It has been only a small part of the eventual program by the Commonwealth government. To put it into context, we have had this small outsourcing contract by the Department of Veterans' Affairs deliberately designed to bring others in with it—an additional 100 per cent work. When the tenderers knew that the Department of Veterans' Affairs workload was going down, the Department of Finance requested and got agreement to come in and use that overrun, which was in the open contract, to bring about substantial savings within the Department of Finance earlier than otherwise would have been available.

That is what happened. We applaud that happening and we are looking forward to additional outsourcing of IT by the government. They have headed off in the right direction and their policy of cluster work for IT outsourcing is the right way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to address the issue of IT outsourcing in government. Before I make some comments in that regard, I would like to note how poorly Senator Gibson has been briefed on this issue. He has made a series of statements today with respect to the actual plan and agenda of OGIT and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey). Many of the statements he has made have been contradicted explicitly by officers of the department throughout the Senate estimates process.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than go over the ground that both Senator Faulkner and Senator Mackay have covered this afternoon in taking note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), I would like to turn to yet another perspective of this particular debacle, this shonky practice, that is worthy of exploring. I would like to turn specifically to the Commonwealth procurement guidelines to which the minister referred in his reply and to which Senator Gibson also referred as being applied as some justification for the process that the Department of Finance has embarked upon in the piggybacking of their IT contract on that of DVA.

Contrary to Senator Gibson's statements and to statements by the minister, there was no explicit clause in the contract with respect to DVA and there certainly was no industry understanding that that contract could be piggybacked. Yes, the minister has been correct throughout the estimates process when it was said that it was not specifically precluded, but nowhere did the DVA contract outline or identify the ability for that contract to be extended beyond that particular department, the DVA.

This has not only been challenged by industry but it has, in fact, solicited a suitable response from OGIT and the department, albeit a belated one. Andy Macdonald, the head of the Office of Government Information Technology, in response to a question from me at estimates, actually said that they will not be proceeding. I will read out the question and the response to get it into context. My question to Mr Macdonald was:

What you are saying is that it was sort of like an unintended consequence of the first stage of IT outsourcing and that the reaction from industry, I would contend, was a bit more than `That's okay' and `It was a good idea' a couple of days down the track. At least that is worthy of some acknowledgment, if not by OGIT, then perhaps Senator Kemp, by the minister—that due process was not proceeded with in accordance, certainly, with the strategy that OGIT had in mind and that in fact goes some way to devaluing or undermining the integrity of the OGIT strategy.
Mr Macdonald's response was this:

I do not think I would be prepared to go that far. As I said earlier, we did not anticipate early joining of clusters, but when the proposition was made we looked at it and on balance we felt that it was legal to do so. It provided an early start, as I indicated earlier. It provided leadership.
He goes on to make a few other comments with respect to getting the process going and responding to industry.

My point here is that the justification for the Department of Finance proceeding in this way is based on a very loose interpretation and reference to the Commonwealth procurement guidelines. But the procurement guidelines that have been quoted consistently by Senator Kemp in estimates, and by Minister Fahey, are not specific. All that they provide is a discretionary clause in section 4. Quite succinctly, 4.4 says:
Exercising discretion in deciding the procurement method.

The Commonwealth does not prescribe the procurement method to be used, nor does it set minimum limits on the number of offers to be sought. Requirements and market conditions vary, and the person responsible for deciding how supplies are to be procured must consider each case on its merits.

That is the discretionary clause that the Department of Finance have used to piggyback their IT contract on the back of DVA. There is nothing else in the procurement guidelines which provides for it. But, if you take it all in context, that particular provision must also have a direct relationship with Finance regulation 43(1) which states:
`A person who decides how supplies are to be procured must choose methods that will promote open and effective competition to the extent practicable.'

It lists a number of examples, including advertising publicly and giving all that have the opportunity to tender the right to do so and the opportunity to do so. This has not been done in this case. It is a shonky process.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that one needs to ask today is this: why has this question not been asked of Mr Fahey, the Minister for Finance, in the lower house? Why have those opposite not been game enough to go into the lower house and ask Mr Fahey the question? They have had ample opportunity. These questions were asked in estimates some weeks ago. There has been question time after question time, but no, they have not gone in and asked Mr Fahey. They have fiddled around here asking questions; they have spent hours in estimates asking questions. Today Senator Lundy commented, when she was describing the clause in the procurement guidelines, `That's the clause they've used to piggyback tender.'

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Ferguson said, and I will now say it again just to make sure they hear: the tender has not been let; the tender has not been finalised; the outcome is not a foregone conclusion. Contrary to what the opposition has said, it is not a foregone conclusion. From the way they have come in here today, you would think that the deal had been done, that it had been signed and sealed, but that is not the case. What has happened is that there has been an exploration of the possibility of piggybacking the Department of Finance's IT outsourcing with DVA's outsourcing. But that has not been done.

Did I hear anybody on the other side of the chamber come in and ask questions about the letting of tenders? When I pursued the letting of a tender for a $5 million contract with a company that was balance sheet insolvent at the time that the then government let a contract to them, I did not hear any of these people bleating then about the contract being wrong and unfair or why was a Dun and Bradstreet check not done to make sure the company was able to carry out the contract. What happened in that case? The company went bankrupt in the middle of the contract. Not one question, not one dorothy dixer did we get about that contract.

But we come in here with a potential situation—not even something that has actually happened—and those opposite waste hours in estimates and spend time in the chamber, not asking the question of the minister directly but asking the minister assisting him, over and over again, when it is not even a foregone conclusion. Talk about a storm in a teacup and making up something that does not really exist! I think that they ought to focus on more definite things. If in fact this contract had been signed, if the deal had been done, then yes, maybe they could have come in and asked some questions, but it has not been done; it is being looked at. And it is within the procurement guidelines; it is legitimate.

I think those opposite do not like the idea of outsourcing; most probably that is the problem. When you look at what happens with outsourcing in the private sector—at companies such as the Macquarie Bank, Qantas, AMP, Integral Energy and, I think, the Commonwealth Bank which shortly is going to outsource its IT—you can see that they have outsourced their IT to obtain better value and to give them greater access to new technology. For example, AMP, which outsourced in 1993, in 1996 said publicly that the savings it has won have vindicated the process and have proved positive.

In the public sector in Victoria, at least seven government agencies have outsourced. These include the State Revenue Office, which expects to save up to 15 per cent over the five years of the contract, and Vicroads, which expects to save $10 million over the same period. In Western Australia a cluster of four agencies, including the Department of Main Roads and the Water Corporation, have outsourced and are saving themselves 20 per cent per year in reduced IT costs.

What we are talking about here is clustering the outsourcing to try and gain the benefit of any excesses built into any contract. There was excess in the DVA contract, and that was what was being examined to see if the Department of Finance could piggyback.

In criticising outsourcing, Labor is forgetting their own outsourcing deal regarding Veterans' Affairs when a projected $10 million was to be saved over a five‐year contract. A new improved contract has been projected to save in excess of 20 per cent. That was announced earlier this year by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott. What we are seeing here is Labor making a mountain out of a molehill over an issue which has not been decided. And that ought to be absolutely clear: it is something that is being explored; it has not been decided.

Those opposite ought to look at issues that really matter. They ought to say, `Look at the things that have happened; we have had savings.' But they are not interested in that. They are interested in running down burrows, chasing rabbits and looking for things that have not actually happened. Talk about paranoia! But this has not yet happened; it is being explored. And, if it was to happen, it would have happened within the procurement guidelines. (Time expired)

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of nuclear testing. Therefore, we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept Nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing, and
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hinchinbrook Development Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy.
We demand the Australian Government:
Review the Actual Means Test for Austudy.
