TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator O'Chee, I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on the scrutiny of the High Court Rules and to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

Recently there has been considerable discussion in Australia about the role and actions of the Courts and the judiciary. At the Federal level this discussion has included aspects of the doctrine of the separation of powers, of the independence of the judiciary and of public statements by judges on matters of present political controversy. It is, however, perhaps less well known that Federal judges also make legislation, with enabling Acts providing for the judges of the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court and, at least until recently, the Industrial Relations Court, to make rules of Court for these respective Courts. These rules are subject to tabling and disallowance and, like all disallowable instruments, are scrutinised by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to ensure that they comply with its high standards of personal rights and parliamentary propriety. This obligation is contained in the terms of reference given to the Committee by the Senate in 1932 and amended in 1979 to take into account the creation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Senate will recall that the Committee's 101st Report, tabled on 8 June 1995, reported on action by the Committee in respect of the principal Industrial Relations Court Rules, Statutory Rules 1994 No 110, which were not gazetted until more than five weeks after they were expressed to come into operation and which therefore appeared to be void for prejudicial retrospectivity. After some discussion the Acting Chief Justice advised that, to avoid doubt, the Rules would be repealed and re‐made in order to operate with unambiguous validity. This was subsequently done, with the exception of one provision which everyone seemed to agree was void. This action could not validate the earlier Rules but would at least ensure that the re‐made Rules were valid. Two years later two sets of amending Rules were not tabled within the statutory period and subsequently ceased to have effect.

At present the Committee is scrutinising the High Court Rules (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 11, which amend the amounts of costs which solicitors who are entitled to practise in the High Court may charge. The Committee was concerned about a number of apparent defects in the Rules and wrote to the Chief Justice. Firstly, the Rules included a number of Notes. Notes included in Commonwealth legislation are usually regarded as illustrative or informative and not part of the legislation itself. These Notes, however, appeared to intend to provide for matters which would normally be included in substantive Rules. Furthermore, the Notes were drafted in a hybrid style which was neither legislation nor information. Moreover, one Note gave the Taxing Officer putative unlimited discretion to override amounts in some items of costs but a discretion up to a limit for other costs and no discretion at all in respect of other costs. Additionally, the Rules provided for witnesses called because of their professional, scientific or other skills or knowledge to be paid $610 a day in addition to lost earnings while other witnesses are paid only $64 a day in addition to lost earnings. This appeared most unfair. Finally, the Rules included gender specific language although for more than a decade this has not been Commonwealth legislative drafting practice.

The Registrar of the High Court replied to our letter advising that the Notes were in fact intended to have substantive effect. This was unexpected advice because, as outlined earlier, this would not usually be the case in Commonwealth legislation which, of course, includes the Rules of the High Court. The Registrar also confirmed our understanding of the Taxing Officer's discretions. The Registrar justified the tenfold difference in costs between what he referred to as "professional" witnesses and, in his words, "ordinary" witnesses, by advising that witnesses rarely appeared before the High Court. Finally, the Registrar advised that the gender specific language would be redressed.

The Committee was not satisfied with the reply and wrote again to the Chief Justice, advising that it prefers that its letters are answered by those to whom they are addressed, although the Committee was grateful to the Registrar for his reply. The Committee asked for further advice on the intention and effect of the Notes, suggesting that if it was wished to provided for the matters in the Notes as legislation, that it may be appropriate to draft and number the provisions in accordance with conventional legislative drafting practice. The Committee also asked about the reasons for the different discretions given to the Taxing Officer and about the apparently unfair provisions for costs of witnesses. The Committee advised the Chief Justice that, in order to preserve its options, the Committee had given a protective notice of disallowance of the Rules.

The Committee's letter was again answered by the Registrar, despite the Committee indicating that it would prefer to have its letters answered by the Chief Justice, because the enabling Act provides for the judges of the High Court, rather than the administrative staff, to make the Rules. The Committee was surprised by this, although we quite understand that the Chief Justice would wish to distance himself from the matters which the Committee raised. The reply was, however, positive in that it advised that a present review would most likely recommend a complete revision of the relevant parts of the Rules which would take into account the Committee's concerns about drafting style. On behalf of the Committee I will be writing to the Chief Justice for the third time about other aspects of the Rules.

The Committee notes that the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 presently before the Senate provides that the Principal Legislative Counsel may provide assistance in drafting Rules of Court if the relevant Chief Justice seeks it. These provisions are appropriate. In the meantime the Committee understands that no statutory provision is needed for the Office of Legislative Drafting to assist the judges when they legislate. For instance, during the scrutiny of the Industrial Relations Court Rules the Acting Chief Justice of that Court advised the Committee that officers of the Attorney‐General's Department had offered to assist the Court to re‐make the Rules.

The Scrutiny by the Committee of the present High Court Rules and the earlier scrutiny of the Industrial Relations Court Rules illustrate the need for supervision by the Committee, on behalf of the Senate, of delegated legislation made by judges. In these cases the Rules did not comply with the standards which the Senate could reasonably expect and action by the Committee has at least partly alleviated the situation. In this context any discussion of the separation of powers usually includes reference to the related doctrine of checks and balances between the legislative, executive and judicial branches. Here it is clear that it was useful and appropriate for the Parliament, which in practice means the Senate, to provide a check and a balance for the High Court judges in their formal legislative role.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator O'Chee, I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 and to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

On 21 November 1996 I reported to the Senate on behalf of the Committee about its scrutiny of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996, which will make numbers of changes to the ability of Parliament to scrutinise and, if the Senate wishes, ultimately to disallow legislative instruments. I reported that, following considerable correspondence with Ministers, several meetings with the Attorney‐General and government amendments of the Bill in the House of Representatives, the Committee supported the Bill, subject to a number of important exceptions.

The Committee has continued its correspondence with Ministers, sending or receiving a further 14 letters on this matter since I last reported to the Senate, with more which I intend to send shortly. Unfortunately three of the four major defects in the Bill still remain, with the responsible Ministers advising the Committee that they will not sponsor government amendments to remedy them. The first defect is a provision for the Attorney‐General to issue conclusive certificates that an instrument is or is not legislative. These certificates would be unreviewable on their merits and not disallowable. The Attorney‐General had argued that such certificates are not legislative in character, but are merely opinions. If that is the case the Senate should have the capacity to express a contrary opinion, and hence such certificates should be disallowable. The second defect is that the Bill excludes instruments providing for national schemes of legislation from parliamentary disallowance. The third defect is that the Bill excludes quarantine proclamations from disallowance, even though breaches of these proclamations incur penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $100,000. The fourth defect related to instruments made in respect of Commonwealth employment. There was some progress in this area, with the Minister undertaking that government amendments would address some of the Committee's concerns although, as I will discuss later, problems remain in one important area.

Government amendments of the Bill as before the Senate have now been drafted. The Committee wrote to the Attorney‐General, the Hon Daryl Williams, as soon as the amendments were prepared, asking for a copy. The Attorney responded at once, in the helpful manner which, as I have reported previously to the Senate, has assisted the Committee in its deliberations on this matter.

The government amendments are relatively brief and are mainly of a type which would not attract the concerns of the Committee. There are, however, two defective aspects of the amendments which the Committee wishes to draw to the attention of the Senate, both of which dilute the scheme of the Bill in relation to parliamentary control of legislative instruments.

The first problem is that the Bill exempts from disallowance all legislative instruments (apart from regulations) made under the key parts of the Migration Act 1958 dealing with the control of the arrival and presence of non‐citizens and with important aspects of the administration of that Act. It is fair to say that without the parts which are exempted the Migration Act would be effectively inoperative. The exempt control parts, for instance, deal with immigration status, unlawful non‐citizens, visas, the "points" system, immigration clearances, search and detention, detention centres and deportations. The exempt administration parts include, among other things, obstructing persons administering the Act, tampering with movements records, offences in relation to escaping from custody, commencement of prosecutions, jurisdictions of courts and review of decisions. In addition, there are numbers of exempt administrative matters which deserve special mention. These include provisions under which the Minister may give general policy directions, exercise a "special" power to refuse or to cancel a visa or to declare a person to be an excluded person. These matters, of course, include the most sensitive areas of immigration and many of them affect personal rights of the most basic kinds. Under the government amendments any legislative instruments made under these provisions will not be subject to parliamentary control.

Legislative instruments made under parts of the Migration Regulations will also be exempt from parliamentary disallowance. The Migration Regulations are actually much longer than the Migration Act and include exempt provisions relating to, among other things, adoption, criminal detention, domestic violence, visa cancellation and giving medical treatment by force to a person in detention. Here again these provisions affect basic personal rights and legislative instruments made under them will not be disallowable.

The Committee draws the attention of the Senate to these exemptions relating to migration as a further instance of the dilution of a fundamental principle of the Bill that Parliament should have full control over legislative instruments. In this context the Committee recalls that on 20 September 1990 the then Deputy Chairman, Senator Bronwyn Bishop, made a statement to the Senate on behalf of the Committee on quasi‐legislation, tabling the Procedures Advice Manual of the then Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Manual was, or perhaps still is, the quasi‐legislation used to administer the Act and the Regulations on a day‐to‐day basis. The Manual consisted of 195 booklets of some 3,300 pages in total, as amended by 41 policy control instructions. The cost of the complete Manual was about $300, with special folders to keep the booklets, which could be bought separately, costing another $100. Much of the Manual or its present day equivalent would be genuinely administrative in nature and thus not appropriate for parliamentary disallowance. On the other hand, however, it seems that portions of it would come within the definition of legislative instrument in the Bill. As such these will be subject to all of the procedural safeguards of the Bill, including registration and tabling, except for disallowance. The Committee suggests that there may be a case for providing for disallowance as an additional parliamentary safeguard.

The other aspect of the government amendments which the Committee draws to the attention of the Senate is the effect of proposed changes to the Defence Act 1903 , the Public Service Act 1922 and the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973. The provisions affected deal with remuneration and conditions of service of, respectively, members of the Australian Defence Force, of the Australian Public Service and of the holders of public office, including among others judges, permanent heads of departments and members of statutory authorities.

The amendments of the Defence Act and the Public Service Act appear to provide for appropriate parliamentary scrutiny and control of determinations affecting members of the ADF and the APS, which will be deemed to be disallowable non‐legislative instruments. The Committee would prefer that these be brought under the general umbrella of the Bill, but the provisions do recognise the rights of Parliament. Indeed, the existing safeguards are improved by requiring determinations to be tabled within six days, instead of the present 15 days, of making. They also provide for the Senate to defer disallowance for six months.

The Committee does, however, have concerns about proposed government amendments to the Bill which will affect the Remuneration Tribunal Act. The proposed amendments to that Act implement long‐standing undertakings given to the Committee by successive Ministers that a defect in the Act would be corrected. The defect is that there is no time limit in respect of a requirement that the Tribunal give a copy of each determination to the Minister, following which the Minister must table the disallowable determination. These undertakings followed the discovery by the Committee that in one case the Tribunal had waited for nine months before giving a determination to the Minister. The government amendments require the Tribunal to give a determination to the Minister within seven days of making. This amendment is appropriate. Unfortunately, there are other significant defects in the Remuneration Tribunal Act, which are not addressed by the amendments and which mean that Tribunal determinations are subject to less effective parliamentary scrutiny than legislative instruments subject to the Bill or disallowable non‐legislative instruments. The Remuneration Tribunal Act still only requires tabling within 15 sitting days of receipt by the Minister, rather than the new standard of six sitting days. More importantly, that Act still requires that any disallowance must take place within 15 sitting days of tabling, rather than the established time, recognised in the Bill, of within 15 sitting days after notice which may itself be given 15 sitting days after tabling. The Bill also provides for a House to defer consideration of a disallowance motion for up to six months, which will not be an option in respect of Tribunal determinations.

The Committee wrote earlier to the Minister about these defects and we have now received a reply. In his reply the Minister advised the Committee that it would be "unfair", to use the Minister's expression, for the judges, permanent heads of government departments and others affected by the Tribunal determinations, to be subject to the "uncertainty" associated with the extension of parliamentary scrutiny of "such significant remuneration outcomes". At the same time the government amendments affecting our ordinary servicemen and women and lower level public servants extend their present "uncertainty" by up to six months while shortening the onset of the uncertainty from a possible 15 sitting days to a possible six sitting days. In other words, the Minister has advised that it would be unfair for those to whom the Minister refers as "the most senior office‐holders in the Commonwealth sector" to be subject to greater scrutiny of their remuneration, while it is apparently acceptable and even desirable for the same amendments to provide for additional parliamentary oversight of the remuneration of the lower levels of Commonwealth employment. The Com mittee was surprised by this advice, which on its face appears to breach principles of equity and fairness and to fly in the face of Australian egalitarian traditions. On behalf of the Committee I will write to the Minister asking for a detailed explanation.

In the meantime the Committee draws to the attention of the Senate the government amendments to the Bill affecting instruments made under the Migration Act and Remuneration Tribunal Act as two more instances where the principles of the Bill are diluted and Parliament is denied its proper scrutiny role.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1997
CGT exemption: disposal of small business assets on retirement

The bill implements the Government's election commitment to allow small business taxpayers to claim an exemption from tax on capital gains made on the disposal of some or all of their active business assets if the proceeds are used for retirement.

The CGT retirement exemption will be welcomed by thousands of small business operators. Owners of small businesses often need to reinvest earnings into their business to sustain growth and increase profitability. These individuals are sometimes not financially able to contribute to superannuation on a regular or even occasional basis. This measure offers a way in which those individuals can place accumulated capital gains into the superannuation environment without making regular contributions.

Taxpayers eligible for the CGT retirement exemption are individuals conducting business as sole traders or in partnership, and companies and trusts where there is a controlling individual who is also an employee of the company or trust.
The Treasurer, in the 1996‐97 Budget, announced measures to extend the principal residence exemption to assist homeowners, and beneficiaries and trustees of deceased estates.

The bill will extend the qualifying period for the capital gains tax (CGT) exemption on disposal of an inherited house from 12 months to 2 years. This will assist many trustees and beneficiaries of deceased estates by giving them more time to dispose of the deceased's principal residence.

The bill will provide a partial CGT exemption for trustees and beneficiaries of deceased estates where the deceased never used the dwelling as a principal residence but beneficiaries of the estate do so.

The provisions will also treat a beneficiary or trustee who acquires a dwelling as a result of a death as having acquired the dwelling at its market value on the date of death if it was wholly the principal residence of the deceased at the time of death. Also, where a person's principal residence is first used for income producing purposes, its market value at that date will be used as its cost base.

The amendments recognise that taxpayers often experience record keeping and compliance problems when disposing of a dwelling that has been used for income producing purposes either for part of the period of ownership or during a period prior to inheritance. The amendments will ensure that taxpayers do not need to keep records of costs incurred before a principal residence is first used for income producing purposes or inherited by them. This will simplify the tax treatment in the majority of cases.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subsidiary company liquidations and capital gains tax

SPEECH.PARA: The bill amends the capital gains tax provisions of the act to reduce a capital gain or loss otherwise realised on the cancellation of shares on the dissolution of a company which is the wholly owned subsidiary of another company. The provisions apply where consideration for the disposal of the shares is equal to the market value of assets distributed in specie to the shareholder company by the liquidator as part of a final distribution.
This measure will ensure that duplication of gains or losses will be avoided as far as possible in these cases.
The bill proposes several amendments to the income tax law in relation to capital and revenue losses. These measures were announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.

The amendments include provisions relating to the offset of current year capital losses, the correction of anomalies in the loss and bad debt provisions relating to companies, the insertion safeguards in the same business test contained in the capital loss provisions, and the tax treatment of payments made in consideration for the transfer of capital and revenue losses.

In addition to these previously announced amendments, the bill proposes to amend the capital loss transfer provisions to give the Commissioner of Taxation unlimited time to amend the assessment of a transferee company in certain circumstances. The Commissioner already has this power in relation to the analogous revenue loss transfer provisions.

Another measure in the bill will ensure that a lessor of depreciable plant or articles under a chattel lease is treated as the owner for taxation depreciation purposes where that leased equipment has become a fixture on another person's land.

Generally, only the owner of the land is the owner of any fixtures on the land, including plant and equipment that may be leased. Technically, that means a lessor may not be entitled to depreciation in respect of leased plant that becomes a fixture on another person's land.
The amendment will result in a more consistent treatment of taxation depreciation allowances for capital expenditure on leased plant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Treatment of payments made under the firearms surrender arrangements

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will implement the announcement made by the Treasurer on 24 July 1996 concerning the tax treatment of payments made under the Compensation for the Surrender of Prohibited Firearms Guidelines issued by the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board. These guidelines were issued as a result of the meeting of State and Territory Police Ministers regarding uniform gun laws held on 10 May 1996.

The amendments will ensure that no income or capital gains tax will be paid in respect of the compensation payments received under the arrangements by taxpayers who are not gun dealers and who used prohibited firearms either in their business or for private purposes.

The amendments will provide two outcomes for gun dealers . They will ensure that there will be no taxable income in relation to a prohibited firearm during the income years when it was held as trading stock. They will also exempt from tax compensation payments received for the loss of business caused by the prohibition of certain firearms.

On 13 December 1996, the Treasurer announced that the Government would move amendments to the R&D tax concession to ensure that companies in partnership could not recreate undesirable syndicate like features.

To that end, the bill ensures that limits on core technology deductions that came into effect on 23 July 1996 will apply to companies in partnership in the same way as to other companies. One of the worst aspects of syndicated R&D related to the immediate deduction of expenditure on overvalued core technology.
The bill also authorises disallowance of deductions of R&D syndicates, where an extension of the syndication period has been granted but the syndicate has breached a condition of that extension.
Further, the bill makes minor corrective measures which ensure that amendments to the R&D provisions made by Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 3) 1996 apply as intended.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Increase in age limit for superannuation contributions

SPEECH.PARA: This measure will increase to 70 years the threshold from which employers are no longer required to provide superannuation support for their employees. This is consistent with the Government's election commitment to allow people over age 65 to continue contributing to a regulated superannuation fund or Retirement Savings Account (RSA) where they maintain a bona fide link with the paid workforce.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rebate for superannuation contributions made on behalf of a low‐income or non‐working spouse

SPEECH.PARA: The bill implements the Government's election commitment to provide a rebate to a person who contributes to superannuation on behalf of a low‐income or non‐working spouse. To be eligible for the rebate, the spouse's assessable income must be less than $13,800.
The rebate is calculated as 18 per cent of contributions up to a maximum of $3,000 in contributions. This limit is reduced where the spouse's assessable income exceeds $10,800.

The bill will adjust the calculation of family tax assistance for taxpayers with exempt foreign earnings, so that they will receive the proper amount of benefit. The method of calculation will be consistent with that for taxpayers who pay tax at a single rate for every dollar of taxable income.

The bill will also give effect to the 1996‐97 Budget announcement that certain remote area housing fringe benefits provided by primary producers will be exempt from fringe benefits tax. Further, the amendments will ensure that, where a primary producer provides free or subsidised residential fuel for use in connection with housing covered by the proposed exemption, the resulting fringe benefit for remote area residential fuel will continue to receive concessional treatment.

The Full Federal Court in Telstra Corporation Ltd v FCT held that certain items used in Telstra's telephone exchanges were exempt from sales tax as electrical fittings. The Government considers that this decision goes beyond the intended coverage of the exemption for electrical fittings and therefore poses a threat to the existing coverage of the wholesale sales tax (WST) system.

Accordingly, the Treasurer announced on November 1996 announced the Government's decision to amend the WST to ensure that goods used in the provision of telecommunication or audio visual services cannot be, from that date, exempt from WST.
These amendments will preserve the integrity of the existing tax base.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dividend imputation for tax exempt entities

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments will cancel the franking surpluses of taxable companies that cease to be wholly owned by tax exempt entities. This will prevent the new owners availing themselves of franking surpluses accumulated during the period when the company was wholly owned by tax exempt entities.

The bill will also make some technical corrections to the Senate's amendment of 12 December 1996 in relation to the exemption available for income derived from the sale, transfer or assignment of mining rights. The corrections will ensure that the Senate's amendment will be given its intended effect.
The bill will also amend the law to provide for income tax deductions to be allowable for gifts to:
the Australian National War Memorial Trust Fund, for gifts made after 1 September 1996 and before 2 September 1998;
the AAP Mawson's Huts Foundation Limited, for gifts made after 17 March 1997; and
the Australia Foundation for Culture and the Humanities Ltd., for gifts made after 8 November 1996.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1997

This bill will amend some aspects of the taxation laws in relation to family tax assistance. The changes are technical in nature, to ensure that family tax assistance is properly delivered to the people who are intended to benefit from the measures.

The amendments will correct some anomalies in the way the law currently works. Firstly, taxpayers with primary production income and a special income component, such as a capital gain, will be able to reduce the rate of complementary tax (if any) by an amount representing family tax assistance, in circumstances where family tax assistance benefits exceed the ordinary tax liability. This will put these taxpayers in the same position as other taxpayers who are liable to pay complementary tax.
Secondly, in the existing law, entitlement to family tax assistance increases the rate of further tax on uncontrolled partnership income. The law will be amended to ensure this is no longer the case.

Thirdly, the complementary tax provisions in relation to family tax assistance will be adjusted for taxpayers with reduced tax‐free thresholds (such as new residents and full‐time students entering the work force for the first time). Currently, these taxpayers are disadvantaged because the provisions are based on the normal tax‐free threshold of $5,400.
The bill also contains a number of technical corrections.
These amendments will apply from 1 January 1997.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal objection the opposition has to the Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997 is the way in which it provides the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer with carte blanche for selling off this asset how, when and in what manner they wish, and, in fact, provides them with the opportunity to sell anything they wish, including fixed infrastructure. SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "That", substitute:

PARA.TAB: (i) develops a coherent policy for the Australian rail industry;

SPEECH.PARA: In November last year, the opposition in fact established a Senate references inquiry into the Brew report and the future role of the Commonwealth in the rail industry in Australia. The major findings of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee, which were tabled in May this year, were that while the Brew report provided an adequate analysis of the financial position of individual AN business units that by itself does not provide a proper framework for the development of rail policy. He said a number of times in evidence to the committee that his job was to simply assess what AN's financial position was and to develop options fundamentally for selling it up. He did not have a brief for advising the government on any kind of coherent rail policy for Australia as a whole.

That Senate committee came to the conclusion that the November 1996 rail package contained very little new funding for the rail industry. In fact, the government's rail reform package of 24 November provided virtually no new money for the Australian rail industry despite the minister's claim that the package was a $2 billion reform measure. Other than the $112 million for redundancies and $20 million for regional adjustment, the remainder of the package was either for existing Commonwealth liabilities or, in the case of the track authority, money already budgeted for.

The Senate committee found that the Commonwealth had not provided any adequate funding for track upgrading, will minimise the value of assets realised at the sale and will run down the value of the Commonwealth's rail assets. The Senate committee also found that NR should not be sold, in any event, prior to the expiration of the NR agreement in 1999 and that before proceeding with the sale process the Commonwealth should develop a coherent land transport policy framework taking into account financial, economic, social and environmental goals and providing medium‐ and long‐term road and rail investment programs in all major corridors.

The 13 May budget saw a further cut of $80 million over four years to the budget of the proposed track authority. The Senate committee heard a significant body of evidence that the pre‐budget allocation would be inadequate for the purposes of providing Australia with a decent interstate rail network. The coalition of course is now committed to the expenditure of $175 million for the track authority compared to the $370 million which was committed by the former Labor government. This shows their significant lack of commitment to this industry.

The concerns that the opposition had to this process were well and truly brought to the attention of the Senate committee in the public hearings that that committee held. As I said before, the principal objection that the opposition has to this legislation is that it is devoted principally to a sell up of the asset without any kind of coherent policy framework for the Commonwealth's future role in rail services in Australia. (a) the Government

PARA.TAB: (i) develops a coherent policy for the Australian rail industry;
(ii) reaches agreement with South Australia and Tasmania on funding assistance for the development of their rail infrastructures;
(iii) provides a Labour Market Adjustment Program for displaced Australian National Railway Commission employees and improves its Regional Adjustment Package;
(iv) guarantees existing passenger service operations and concession arrangements; and
(v) guarantees the employment and training of apprentices currently employed by the Australian National Railways Commission until the completion of their contracts—

SPEECH.PARA: And, importantly, this was a matter that was canvassed at the some length during the Senate estimates process—

PARA.TAB: (i) demonstrates that all employees that have left Australian National since 24 November 1996 as a result of work-related illness or injury have been offered a redundancy payment; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill is yet another sale bill. I suppose there is still Australia Post to sell. Then we will be into selling things like AQIS—I suppose the farmers might want to buy it—or perhaps United Fruit. Of course we could always sell this building to overseas interests and lease it back.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I arrived in the Senate in 1993 I have been speaking about the importance of rail. It was in the fuel tax debate in October of that year that I outlined some of the reasons the Greens WA feel rail is important. They include the fact that per tonne of freight rail uses roughly one-third of the fuel used if that freight had been carried by road. Given the huge distances involved in transporting freight from the eastern states to Western Australia and even from Sydney to Melbourne or Brisbane, shifting long‐haul freight from road to rail would help our greenhouse record quite a bit.

In fact, just shifting one‐quarter of the freight now travelling by road between Melbourne and Sydney onto rail freight services would reduce CO2 emissions for the transport sector by 10 per cent. It would cut it by 20 per cent if we could get half the road freight into rail. Not only that, by reducing emissions, we would reduce the estimated cost to Australia for air pollution from $787 million, according to the information I cited back in 1993.

We would use a fraction of the space that roads do and dramatically reduce accidents. The train fatality rate is only 11 per cent that of trucks and we would avoid the stupidity of horrific accidents like the one a few years ago when a road train hauling grain had a brake failure coming down the hill into Perth from Mundaring and ran through a light and several cars.

Of course government seems set to go the other way. In the time since I initially quoted these figures, rail funding has declined. Rail services have been wound back. We have had massive campaigns on behalf of road funding like the infamous `fix Australia: fix the roads' campaign. We have seen the Premier of Western Australia approve bringing road trains right into the city limits of Perth. In Queensland, I now understand they are supporting road trains with three trailers.

The federal government raised the fuel taxes on rail in 1993 and then hit it with a massive increase from 6c to 32c—an increase for rail fuel of 26c per litre! The government claimed this was for environmental reasons, to prevent the use of dirtier fuel. The rail services use exactly the same fuel; it is just reclassified from fuel oil to diesel fuel. The fuel itself remains the same. In fact, the level of what is acceptable for sale as diesel has gone down.

The evidence is overwhelming that from an environmental standpoint it is preferable to have at least long‐haul freight go by rail. From a health standpoint it is better. From a land use standpoint it is better. From the standpoint of the amenity of towns, such as Northam, Southern Cross and so on, it is better. From the standpoint of savings on the cost of building and maintaining roads it is better. From the standpoint of paying for health services and paying for by-passes to get the stream of trucks off the main streets of small towns it is better. In almost every sensible, practical sense it is better to have at least long‐haul freight on rail instead of road.

Short‐haul freight also has advantages. There is no reason not to have a good distribution system. Evidence from the rail industry is that the trunk routes operate much more profitably when they are fed and feed into a distributed regional rail network. In many, if not most, places where we can displace freight from road to rail the environment and community is the winner.

Instead, in Western Australia we have logs and mineral sands going by road through all the beautiful small towns in the south west—places people go to get away from traffic and from the bustle of the urban environment. In Bridgetown there is an incessant stream of log trucks. In towns like Bunbury we have mineral sands trucks driving through suburban streets, leaking radioactive sand that blows onto the verges and against the houses lining the roads. The routes can be traced by geiger counter. The union says that they should be travelling by covered railway cars. Why listen to the unions? Why think of health when there are a few cents to be made? The fact that there is a rail line nearby just makes the situation less comprehensible.

For shorter distances, particularly in more built‐up areas, the use of electric rail is practical and studies on passenger rail by the Institute for Science and Technology Policy at Murdoch University indicate the greenhouse emissions from electric rail are less per passenger kilometre than for either road or buses and substantially less when we talk about light rail systems. They also have the advantage of being quiet and keeping emissions at the power plant instead of in urban streets. They are currently using coal rather than scarce liquid fuel but they can be converted to renewably sourced electricity in the future.

Part of the problem is that we see roads as some sort of free good in our society. Rails cost money and the cost of maintaining a rail network is fairly easy to quantify and assign to the rail carrier. The cost of maintaining a road network, on the other hand, is seen as a social cost, something used by everyone—private cars, buses, business vehicles, trucks and road trains. It is used for many purposes: tourism, going to work, doing private business, going to parties, long distance transport, cruising through urban centres on weekend evenings, and haulage. We assign the cost of the rail system to the trains. We do not properly assign the cost of roads. We might be able to look at the money the Commonwealth puts in specifically for roads, but road funding comes from general transfers to the states.

The states spend money on roads, and local shires spend money on roads, and this in cludes things like forced resumption of lands for highway building or upgrading. Then, there are the contingent costs such as the establishment and maintenance of a traffic network, the system of lights and signals. There is the cost of policing all those individuals making individual decisions. What percentage of police time is spent on traffic related duties? All that is part of the expense of roads. Of course, there are studies that have been done on this in other places. I know there have been studies in relation to Western Australia. I know there have been extensive studies in the United Kingdom and related areas. I am sure there have been studies in the United States.

How many accidents are there? How many health related issues, lung problems, lead problems, problems with new additives like benzene and problems with ozone and photochemical smogs are there? What about the costs of establishing parking spaces, costs to business, costs to the texture of our city centres and costs in terms of creating urban deserts? All of these are costs of favouring roads over rail.

I am left in a fairly invidious position. I firmly believe it is in the best interests of both people and the environment of Australia to actively pursue a strategy of support for rail as a transport form for freight and passengers, for urban and rural communities, for short‐ and long‐distance transport. I think we need to move away from roads and cars. At the same time, I do not believe that the ALP in government was particularly supportive of rail. This government has a particular hatred for rail, eclipsed only by its hatred of anything to do with Australian national shipping.

In such a context, rail is always presented as an expense. Increasing capitalisation of rail by government is, these days, unthinkable. It is nearly impossible for rail interests within government to seem to have as much of a claim as the road lobby, so rail will always be under‐represented. People in the departments must feel it is almost a lost cause when they come to their minister and then to cabinet, if they do these days, with proposals for spending on rail.

BREAK.PARA: On the other hand, in the case where governments are not pulling their weight in relation to developing, creating and recapitalising rail, there might be people genuinely interested in rail and the prospect of reversing the decline of rail. There might be investors with a commitment to such a reversal where we could see potentially a reversal in the decline of rail use. It might be the case that rail could be better under a private sector, but you need to have, as Senator Collins suggested, some sort of policy. We have not seen that. We are being asked to sign a blank cheque.

There is no guarantee that what we will get is a good bidder, one committed to an extensive and growing rail system. There is no guarantee that such a bidder will win. There was a suggestion at the time of privatisation in New Zealand that private rail interests should simply close down all the branch lines and stick to the backbone route. That is the kind of thing governments are doing. In this particular case, the buyers found that the backbone was fed by the branches and so they did not close them. But who is to say that that particular company is typical? In the United States, historically road, fuel and petroleum interests have purchased tram systems just to close them down. Those decisions are now being reversed, but we have no guarantee that a similar kind of thing will not happen here.

I have tried to think of ways that we could encode an obligation on a buyer to keep branches open and services running to ensure that the rail network remains at least as extensive as it is now. We have tried to think of how we could put a requirement that the buyer work for an objective of displacing road freight into rail. We have tried to think of how we could guarantee passenger services are maintained and that road and rail container terminals are the world's best. We have tried to figure out a way to draft a requirement that the long distance passenger trains like the Indian Pacific, the Ghan and the Overland are maintained as affordable overland passenger trains and not just tourist attractions.

In the short time that we have had available in the context of this bill and the way the government is breaking up parts of this system, to put such requirements into law would be extremely difficult. Unfortunately, it is proposed to sell Australian National piecemeal, with the biggest parts being the Tasmanian network and the South Australian network. We still do not even know what will happen with Track Australia. If and when it is properly established, it will probably be sold along with National Rail.

I understand that there might be little opposition in the long run for the sale of the railways. This decision should not be rushed. I will continue to say that the best thing would be for government to take a long-term view, a proactive position, and work to shift long haul freight to ship and rail. It would be very much in the interest of Australia in terms of reducing our vulnerability to oil price changes so we could not put our hands up bleatingly in the international arena and say, `Pity us. We're so vulnerable.'

In relation to the petroleum products that we all need to consume at the moment, we could reduce that dependence. We could reduce our greenhouse emissions and address the real problems facing the world, particularly the ones likely to impact on Australian agriculture and fisheries. We could reduce dependence in terms of working positively to create a world where the choice does not need to be car ownership or isolation and disempowerment. We could reduce dependence in terms of general health and amenity and the reduction of a myriad of external expenses.

I understand that Senator Brown has some amendments that he would like to put to this bill, but there is a proposal from the ALP that the bill is taken for further consideration and that we ask the government to look to see exactly what policy it is pursuing before rushing into this. I do understand the distress that is occurring within this industry in relation to decapitalisation, running down of capital, and the running down of the ability for rail freight and passenger rail to compete effectively.

I understand the distress that is occurring, but I also believe that we would not be acting responsibly as a Senate unless we had a bit more information upon which to make a decision as to whether or not Australian National is to be privatised and on what basis Australian National is to be privatised. Under those conditions, I indicate that I will support the ALP's second reading amendment to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate opposition to the Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997 in its current form, and to make some comments in relation to it. First, there seems to be a trend in the pursuit of legislation by this government to leave a lot out of the bill and in the power of the executive. Senator Margetts, in effect, has touched upon that aspect of this bill in her indication of support for Labor's amendment on the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the debate on the Reform of Employment Services Bill, we have seen an indication that the government will use other legislation and executive power to implement its policy, if the bill is not passed in the form it desires. In relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill, we have seen legislation which goes far beyond the expressed intention of the government in relation to its policy on work for the dole. And, in this case, we see a bill which allows for the sale and winding up of the Australian National Railways Commission, the sale of its assets, and the empowering, effectively, of two ministers with the authority—without reference to the parliament, as I understand it—to decide upon the track access regime for this country and the maintenance regime for that track, and to place all of the arrangements that are integral to its continued operation in this country beyond parliamentary scrutiny.

As I say, in relation to the legislative package that this government is pursuing, we have an alarming trend which is reflected again in this bill: a desire to avoid parliamentary scrutiny and leave matters in the hands of the executive. Of course, it can be said that oppositions complain about, and governments like, the situation where matters are kept within the control of the executive and beyond parliamentary scrutiny. I think it is fair to say that it is not necessarily a good thing for this country to have its parliamentary executive running the country, without proper reference to parliament. There will always be a debate about where the line starts and finishes.

But in this case, I think we are talking about one of the most important aspects of this country's economic base: its transport infrastructure. As part of that, rail infrastructure is critical, given the future and looking to the 21st century of this country in relation to its trade and its internal relationships—the relationships between the states. We have here a bill which seems to be proceeding from a point of deciding to sell an asset and then deciding upon policy later. This, as I say, is a concern which underpins my concern about the whole of this bill.

Given the impact of this bill and that which it will have on the whole of the rail industry, I want to emphasise even further the impact it is likely to have on the state of Tasmania, the state that I represent in this chamber. With this legislation we see a lack of any specifics as to how it will deal with the question of creating a track authority for the future. But with the state of Tasmania, the situation is that there is no intent to protect the permanent way, the basic track, in the state of Tasmania; there are no guarantees that that will be maintained.

As I have said, for some time this government has been telling the people of Australia that the long‐term security of the track is ensured, because the management of the track will be handed over to the proposed national track authority. That has not been set up in this bill; it is a matter that has been left to the ministers. There is no such authority; there is no such proposal for Tasmania.
In relation to this matter, the Senate references committee, in its report on the Brew report, on the continuing role of the Commonwealth in the Australian rail industry, said:
If the Commonwealth proceeds to sell Tasrail—
which is the Tasmanian part of Australian National Railways—

the Commonwealth should guarantee the continued operation of the railway, including provision of capital investment funds to maintain its modernisa tion program. This would compensate Tasmania for its effective exclusion from the benefits of the proposed track authority.

I must say that I have been somewhat concerned by the way in which the need for these sorts of guarantees were dismissed, firstly, in the Brew report; secondly, by the government; and, thirdly, by the cavalier way in which the Tasmanian government has dealt with this matter. The Tasmanian government has simply been satisfied, as it were, with letting the market provide. It has said, `Sell Tasrail, and the market will provide us with a solution. We don't need any formal guarantees, we don't need anything in black and white, we don't need anything in this bill. We just want the asset sold; we don't want to take any responsibility for it.'

The Senate inquiry makes it clear that Tasmania is disadvantaged by that position. It needs guarantees of the continued operation of the railway. Also, it needs the provision of capital investment funds to maintain its modernisation program.

The recent estimates program allowed me to ask some questions of Australian National in regard to its Tasrail operation. AN made it clear that basically, without the debt repayments that are allocated to its annual performance, Tasrail will be operating on a break-even basis; it is not a money losing proposition. That is, with a track infrastructure that needs some further work and given another couple of years of appropriate capital investment, the rail system, I believe, will be operating profitably.

The committee also recommended that this government, the federal government, pursue the option offered in the Brew report of eliminating the AN debt in Tasrail and returning the system to the Tasmania government. This government has indicated it is not going to do that—and that is probably because the Rundle government in Tasmania has indicated that it does not want the railway, it does not want to take on the responsibility of running the railway, it does not want to take on the responsibility of guaranteeing the maintenance of an operating railway system in Tasmania. It wants to wash its hands of the matter, just as this government wants to wash its hands of the rail system in Tasmania and leave it to the market.

One can argue that perhaps the market will do it better. Perhaps it will. But the other side of that question is that perhaps it will not. Perhaps it will not wish to continue operating. Perhaps it will only seek to operate the most profitable sections of the rail line. If that is the case—and that is a possibility in relation to the operation of railways in Tasmania—we could see a greater amount of traffic on Tasmania's roads.

There has been a lot of investment in the road system in Tasmania over the last 10 to 15 years. In some areas I would have to say that the road system is reasonable. It could do with some upgrading from time to time. If you increase the heavy vehicle usage of the road system, history has shown us that that system will deteriorate rather quickly. We see that some sections of the roads have been badly damaged by heavy traffic in part because they were not properly made.

I have made comments elsewhere about the inactivity of the Tasmanian government in relation to pursuing the correction of that situation and the funding of the rebuilding of those sections of road. If, as inevitably it will happen if you cut down on the rail system in Tasmania, there is more traffic on Tasmanian roads, there will be more damage. I believe it is quite short-sighted of the Tasmanian government to find itself in a position where it may require additional funds to maintain its roads because of its stance taken in relation to the sale of the Tasrail system.

Mainland Australia, through this government, has been given the appearance of the commitment to maintain rail infrastructure through the national track authority. We have not even been granted that. We simply do not know what the future will be for track operation in Tasmania. In any case, this bill does not give us any guarantees on rail infrastructure. As I said, those matters are missing from the bill. We do not know how the track maintenance regime will be guaranteed, what access obligations will exist or how the Commonwealth will ensure funding. Indeed, we know very little about the future of the track system in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: What we do know is that in the last budget this government cut the amount of money allocated from $370 million to $185 million—not the $175 million that the minister announced in his press release immediately after the budget. In addition, again from my state, there is no safety or regulatory framework in existence when the rail network is sold—if it is to be sold—under this bill. That is an important issue.

How can we hand the currently regulated system back to a private operator in an environment where there is not an existing non-government safety or regulatory framework in place? Surely that is a matter which is a priority prior to the effecting of the sale under this legislation. This bill does not address that. This government has not addressed that, and neither has the Tasmanian government. The Tasmanian parliament is in recess for three months and it will be rather difficult for it to pass any legislation while it is not sitting.

The other aspect which I will touch on briefly is the potential for further job losses in Tasmania. It has been said that there have already been job losses with Australian National and with Tasrail. A lot of jobs have gone in this area. The fact is that a lot of jobs have gone in a lot of industries. In this case, there are no guarantees that the level of employment in a privatised industry will be anywhere near the level of employment which currently exists around Australia and, in particular, with Tasrail in Tasmania both now and in the future.

The impact of further job losses in Tasmania cannot be emphasised enough. If there is a significant impact with that closure, it will be on top of the significant impact on the Tasmanian economy, particularly in the north‐east of the state where unemployment is running at around 11 per cent and is likely to increase with recently announced closures of manufacturing and service industries in the north-east of the state. There is nothing in this bill that will assist us here.

With regard to the involvement of the Australian people in the decision making process through this parliament, in my view the government does not have the right to take that process away. There are also issues that need to be addressed with regard to the entitlements for the workers of the Australian National Railways. In the recent Senate estimates inquiry, I asked questions about both the superannuation scheme for those workers and the denial of redundancy payments to workers who had been injured whilst employed by Australian National.

Workers at Australian National in the past have been denied access to redundancy payments on the basis of their entitlement to workers compensation. Whilst AN have reviewed this policy, we are still waiting for confirmation that all workers who have left AN since the closure announcement who have been victims of a workplace accident or injury will be treated the same as other workers and receive their entitlement to redundancy from AN—in particular, circumstances that I raised with the chief executive officer of Australian National.

The AN principal superannuation scheme ignores the issue of redundancy as it does not allow for full vesting for employees until they have achieved 15 years service under that scheme, as I am informed. If full vesting were granted, I am led to believe that some 320 employees would receive a more equitable package. As I understand it, the superannuation scheme would be left with about a $5 million surplus if they do not change the scheme's rules so as to provide full vesting. That full vesting would be provided for within that surplus if it were allowed.

The Brew report commissioned by the minister recommended that the Tasrail operation could be handed to the Tasmanian government with appropriate adjustment to financial assistance grants. It would appear that this recommendation, however, was deleted from the version of the executive summary which was initially handed down. I am wondering why that happened and whether there was some discussion between the two governments before it occurred. If that is the case, I wonder how appropriate and how principled such an action is.

In conclusion, I would like to say that this bill does not address the significant concerns the public may have about the direction of this government on rail policy—indeed, if it has a direction—and it does not properly address the need for accountability through this place. I commend the opposition amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Greens are opposed to the privatisation of the national rail system. I, in particular, am opposed to the privatisation of the Tasmanian system. The idea behind this is that in some way or other private enterprise can run these systems as a better service to the public than the government can, but there is a lot of global experience to show that that is not the case. I am amazed at the arrangements being offered to private enterprise which, as things stand, are not being offered to the state government of Tasmania if it takes over Tasrail.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasrail carries 16 per cent of the state's freight. It has not had passengers since the late 1970s, but that option should remain open in an age in which the clean, green and clever direction is the job prospective and economic prospective direction for Tasmania as we move out of the age of hydro‐industrialisation.

Tasrail was handed from the state Labor government of Eric Reece in a very, I think, short-sighted move—or at least coming after a long period of neglect under successive Labor governments in Tasmania—to the Whitlam government in the early 1970s. Just before that, the same Premier, Eric Reece, had taken the train ride from Strahan to Queenstown on the Abt railway, which had a cog system up the centre because of the steepness of the grade. The idea had been borrowed from Swiss engineers and Swiss mountain railway systems. But there was no future seen for this railway with the closure of the smelters at Queenstown and the emergence of other options.

Here we are just three decades down the line and there are groups of people and businesses in Tasmania working to involve state government and anybody else they can to raise $20 million to put the Abt railway back, because it would be a magnificent attractant for the 100,000 tourists a year going to Strahan to visit the mighty Macquarie Harbour and Gordon-Franklin river systems, which previous Labor and Liberal govern ments wanted to flood—you might remember—at the start of the 1980s.

How short-sighted that, for the want of being able to look ahead a little, that railway system was pulled out. Now people are trying to raise $20 million to put it back in, because it would be a good thing to capitalise on Tasmania's wild and scenic reputation internationally. It would be a good thing as far as job creation and economic prosperity for the depressed west coastal region of Queenstown is concerned.

Here we are in a situation where the government, through this legislation, is likely to sell off the whole of the Tasrail system for the same amount—about $20 million. That is one basic estimate. What extraordinary short-sightedness. What a failure to learn from history. What a propensity to repeat the mistakes of the past. What an indictment of the short‐sightedness of the material politics that predominate in this place and, indeed, in most chambers of parliament around this country and around the world in 1997.

When you look at the Tasrail system, it has, like other rail systems, had to compete against the road system, which has been hugely financed and assisted by serial governments at state and federal level. Massive amounts of money have subsidised the rail freight system. Where Tasrail needs to put aside a few million dollars each year to continue the upgrade of its lines and, hopefully, to move towards realignment of the system as well as upgrading of rolling stock, it cannot get it. But governments have no trouble in subsidising the average heavy transport on the road to the tune of somewhere between $10,000 and $30,000 per annum. Billions of dollars go into the road system, not to provide for the needs of you and I in our cars, Mr Acting Deputy President MacGibbon, but to provide for the wear and tear of heavy road transport.

We are in a situation where, when I asked the minister for reasons why a brand new section of the national highway system near my home in Liffey in Tasmania was suddenly being dug up and resurfaced recently, the answer was, `Well, yes, that is costing $X million because the laboratory got the strength of the building materials wrong.'

BREAK.PARA: What the laboratory did not get wrong was the access onto that highway system off the Oaks Road at Bracknell, which they had forgotten to put in and, at great expense, were putting in after the event of the road being built. What they appeared to get wrong—the minister might cavil with me on this—is the building of a major distributor near Deloraine across to the new system. Then there was a decision within 24 months to undertake a new configuration of the road system which warranted a new distributor. They pulled out the old one. There was a very high embankment system across the Meander River flats for some kilometres, but they pulled it out. There were massive works to remove the whole new road and put it a few hundred metres across to the east.

There we have millions of dollars being spent on fixing up a road system that should have been fixed in the first place, and it almost goes without comment. But if the rail system happens to ask for some millions of dollars to fix up its rolling stock or its track, there is an outcry about public subsidies. We have got this extraordinary system whereby, if it is for the roads and the big transport companies using the roads, billions of dollars can be put aside and that is not seen as a public subsidy. But if a much smaller and more modest amount is to be set aside to ensure that the rail system is up to date, improving and competitive, it is not the people so much as the governments—the competing political parties—that cry foul and say, `This system is not working properly. It is running at a loss. We had better do something about it. Let's privatise it.'

Let us look at the Tasmanian rail system. On the most recent figures that I have seen, it is roughly in balance, with a $22 million income and a $22 million debit. If my figures are not wrong, some $4 million or $5 million of that is set aside to pay the interest on accumulated debt. In this legislation, the government is proposing to sell off that rail system minus the debt. It does not take Einstein to look at those figures and realise that the government is saying to private enterprise, `We will give you a $4 million to $5 million profit‐making enterprise straight off. You will be able to say, "We are running this at a profit whereas the state couldn't."'

That is where the Greens come in. We say, `If you are going to sell it off to private enterprise and exculpate their debts, let us put it back to the state government as a public concern. Let us put it back to the people of Tasmania and take those debts out and we will instantly have a rail system, working on freight, that is making $4 million to $5 million a year.' That sounds like a good thing to me.

Michael Foley MHA, the Greens spokesperson on transport in Tasmania, is working at that end of the line to get the minority state Liberal government to see that this is not a debt‐making problem but a profit‐making asset if it is to be handed out of the federal arena and out of Commonwealth ownership free of debts. From there, there is no doubt that there needs to be upgrading of not only the rolling stock but also the management system in Tasmania. Looking at the figures, it has not passed my notice that, since Tasrail was handed to the federal authorities in about 1975, the numbers of people in the employ of Tasrail have fallen from something like 1,700 to something like 175. Here again, we have got part of the reason why Tasrail's books look so promising. Tasrail has been scaled right back—or `downsized', which I think is the common parlance for getting rid of jobs in both private and public industry.

One can see again that it has been made ripe for handing across to private enterprise, which has had the hard job done for it through the numbers being scaled down to make the profit line look better. Tasrail ought to be just as ripe for a state government to take it on, with or without the redundancies—leave that optional for the workers—with the expertise available to make sure this system stays in public hands.

I want to give further reasons, besides the financial ones, as to why it should stay in public hands. I doubt that there is going to be any caveat in this sale to private enterprise, if it goes ahead, that says, `You must keep the current Tasrail system as it is. You can't close components of it.' It is very important that we understand that, without such a caveat, we are going to see further wind‐backs in the Tasrail system and further situations in which, a few decades down the line, people will be gnashing their teeth and saying, `If only we hadn't pulled that lump of rail out, what a great tourism asset it would be.'

One of the things that is failing at government level in Tasmania, and has been for some decades, is the ability to see this change in the economic direction Tasmania must be taking. Stand up on the line just west of Burnie Central and you will see it slowly rusting because it has been out of use since its single freight purpose was brought to an end 12 months or so ago. Better still, if you drive along the road that is somewhere near that line, you will recognise that you are in one of the best coastal pieces of scenery as far as rail access is concerned anywhere in the world. That line then runs through to Ulverstone and on to Devonport.

People sing the praises of the rail trip from San Francisco through to Los Angeles and down through Santa Barbara, but on Tasmania's north coast we have something that is better. Indeed, it is so close to the sea that in places there have been breakwaters built to prevent high seas in times of storm washing across the railway line and washing it out. It is a magnificent piece of coastal railway if you have got in mind scenery and tourism in the future.

When the folk from Wisconsin regional rail—one of the potential buyers—were here last week, I pointed out to them the potential on that rail because it is very important that they go and look at it if this legislation gets through and they are successful tenderers—not with a view to pulling the railway line up but with a view to new utilisation. Sadly, I have to admit that other than by the Greens in Tasmania there is very little of the vision that would see that line being put to the prospective use that it has been. Sadly again, maybe it does take people from elsewhere to come along and see that potential and to capitalise on it before the opportunity is irrevocably lost by the ripping up of the rail service.

Let us not make the mistake of Eric Reece and the Abt railway line. Let us see Tasmania as having special potential not only in the area of freight but also in the area of scenic and tourist potential with the existing rail set‐up. It is magnificently placed for that but it is going to take a new vision if that is to be undertaken.

By the way, I had a good yarn with Wisconsin rail the other day and I understand that it is basically a freight enterprise. It has passenger interests in New Zealand and Canada but that is not its major purpose. I would be concerned that whoever does take over Tasrail looks at the real potential for introducing scenic transport as a complement to Tasmania's major job creator for the future, and that is its internationally outstanding wild and scenic beauty. One only has to see the full trains in summer, when they occasionally run from Hobart to Mount Field so that people can enjoy both steam rail and the scenic amenity there, to understand how popular it is domestically and how easily it could be converted into an international and interstate enterprise for the creation of jobs and the stimulus of the Tasmanian economy.

Let me conclude by shorthanding, if you like, the Greens' alternative to this legislation. There are two components. First, we believe that Tasrail should not be sold as a component of the national rail system but should be divested from the Commonwealth, if it must be, as a discrete entity, because it is a discrete entity. Secondly—and I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to this end—if it is to be sold divested of its debts, therefore in a profitable configuration, the Tasmanian government, on behalf of the Tasmanian people, ought to be first offered that option of taking it back in the interests of Tasmania and the wider potential uses for rail—its long‐term viability with new options to the traditional ones of carting coal, carting logs to woodchip mills and in general carting freight.

It has gone through a long and depressing phase but we are now entering a new phase full of options for Tasmania. The Greens believe that those options should be investigated and are best enhanced by Tasmanians, working through the Tasmanian government.

I oppose the legislation as far as its impact on Tasmania is concerned. I will be moving constructive amendments at the committee stage. I hope that the government will see them in that light and support them. If not, I hope that the other components of this Senate will support the option of Tasrail going back into the hands of the Tasmanian people as the Commonwealth moves to divest itself of Tasrail, but without the debts and therefore as a profitable enterprise, to some other agent. Let that agent be the Tasmanian people. Let that new owner be the Tasmanian people and not private enterprise from somewhere else which will have a much more constricted view of the opportunities, potential and needs of rail in the future of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saddened also that in the debate in the lower house, the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), whose electorate in New South Wales contains a significant part of the Indian Pacific rail link, chose to talk a lot about Port Augusta.
