We know that it is a vital link for tourism and that hard work has been put into its development. This service is important for tourism but, as I keep repeating, it is an extremely important public transport link.

That was brought home to us when the committee, of which I am a participating member, held hearings in the city of Broken Hill. Sure, the mayor of Broken Hill is a Labor Party member and, sure, the Labor vote in Broken Hill is about 70 to 72 per cent. But even the chamber of commerce was opposed to the privatisation of Australian National. Chambers of commerce are not normally known in this country as being mad keen supporters of the Australian Labor Party or the anti‐privatisation position, but that is the position of the chamber of commerce in Broken Hill; they also oppose the sale of Australian National.

One of the reasons why people are opposing the sale of Australian National is that nobody can give a cast‐iron guarantee that the Indian Pacific and other transport services are going to remain on the western line. There are grave concerns that those services will be re‐routed through Melbourne and Adelaide. Whilst we have no problems with people in Melbourne and Adelaide having a rail service and being part of this service, the people of Broken Hill, Ivanhoe, Menindee, Condobolin and Parkes are very concerned about what the impact on them will be.

I spoke last week in another debate about the fact that, when there is rain, the Indian Pacific and the line between Ivanhoe and Broken Hill is the only land transport corridor available. The roads are gravel; and it is hardly gravel because it is black soil plain country. It is the black soil mud that sticks to you. You stick to it in the dry and it sticks to you in the wet and it does not need a great deal of wet to stick to you. These are the sorts of things that people have to contend with.

BREAK.PARA: The people of Ivanhoe have a small hospital facility but, if they require hospitalisation for significant problems, their nearest public hospital is Broken Hill, over 300 kilometres up the track. They have the Royal Flying Doctor Service which evacuates people from Ivanhoe to Broken Hill, but they are not able to evacuate the relatives of those people. So Ivanhoe relies upon both the Indian Pacific and the state rail service that took over from the Silver City service which was reintroduced by the Labor government in New South Wales last year. They have to rely on that to get them to Broken Hill.

Menindee is another small community. These communities have been railway towns and have provided significant services and support to the railways in this country for over 100 years. The number of people employed on the railway in those areas has certainly decreased with the advent of diesel and the phasing out of steam. There is no longer the need for the water refuelling stops to be strategically placed and the journeys—thank God—are faster. Therefore, there is less need for workers but it is still a very important service to Menindee.

In 1995‐96, the Indian Pacific brought 27,000 tourists into Broken Hill and it has been estimated that that expenditure is around $6.8 million or 80 full‐time jobs. Broken Hill is a town whose history is steeped in the mining industry but, as with all mining communities, the ore body eventually runs out. Over the last decades, the number of people employed in the mines has gone down from 4,500 to 700. There are now 1,100 people employed around Broken Hill in the tourist industry, so you can see that tourism is of vital significance to the people of Broken Hill.

The tourist industry in Broken Hill is beginning to devise packages that dovetail in very well with the Indian Pacific and with the state rail train so that people can spend three or four days in the Hill and go out and see the outback, and it really is the accessible outback. Not far from Broken Hill is Silverton, which is a significant area for film production. Just past Silverton is the Mundi Mundi Plain. When you stand at sunset on the escarpment on the Mundi Mundi Plain and look west, you just see red dirt. You see the desert; you see the harsh interior of this country. This is something that, in the last financial year, 27,000 tourists were able to avail themselves of. A lot of these were Australian tourists who do not want and cannot afford to be on trains at the high priced end of the market. They are a wide variety of people, including backpackers. We know from the figures that have been done that this is the number of people who actually arrived on the Indian Pacific, because the Broken Hill Tourism Board is a very well‐managed and vibrant board and they can tell you where their tourists are coming from.

I think it is vitally important that people take cognisance of the fact that these trains do have a valuable contribution to make to this country. Even in New South Wales, which is often thought of as being Sydney, Newcastle and Wollongong, we have significant areas of isolation and remoteness. We have significant distances, and when you get out towards Menindee and the Hill, you find that you are joining with areas in northern South Australia and the east of Western Australia. There is not a great deal from Broken Hill until you get to Kalgoorlie.

What concerns me about this package to sell off Australian National is that in the rail reform package $112 million was set aside for redundancies and so forth and $20 million for regional adjustment. The rest of the $2 billion package was for existing liabilities or money that was already budgeted. This year's budget cut $80 million over four years to the proposed track authority. The government has now made a commitment to that of $175 million, as opposed to the $370 million that the previous Labor government was offering.

These are just indications as to why the people of Broken Hill and those areas do not feel secure about the future of Australian National. They see no guarantees and they see cuts to expenditure. That, for them, is a very worrying situation—of course it is a worrying situation. These isolated communities have every right to be worried. As I said, the Indian Pacific is for the people of Broken Hill, Ivanhoe and Menindee. It is a public transport service. It is not a service that is there so that people can choose whether or not to use it. If people do not use the train, what are they left with? They are left with the option of flying. If they want to go to Sydney they can fly with Hazelton from Broken Hill direct to Sydney. The full air fare is over $700. There will be occasions when they can get discount fares, but $450 is the usual fare. If people wish to go to Melbourne they can fly, but they have to go via Mildura. Of course, sometimes the only way to get to Sydney is via Adelaide or via Melbourne.

These are long trips involving many hundreds of dollars. They are well beyond the means of a pensioner, and there is a significant aged community in Broken Hill. With the downturn in mining, people have moved away. The younger people have moved away; the older people have chosen to stay. The people living in the Broken Hill area still like to go and visit their families who live away from them. That is very important to them. If they have not got a train to go on and they cannot afford an aircraft fare, what are they left with? They are left with bus travel. They can catch a bus that connects with the XPT at Dubbo. To do that, they have to leave Broken Hill at 3 a.m. in the morning—a great time—and face a nine‐ or 10‐hour road journey. Of course, the buses have also got to miss the kangaroos and the emus. There is a fair number of them out there.

Most of the pensioners in Broken Hill—and I have spoken to many elderly people in Broken Hill—do not like bus travel. They like train travel. When they are doing a journey of that significant length they need to be able to get up and move around. They need to be able to use the toilet facilities, and they find this easier on a train. There is also the problem of access. People find there is a marked difference between getting on and off a train and getting and on and off a bus—a huge difference. They find getting on and off the train very easy. The train station at Broken Hill has a very good ramp. You can just about drive right up to the station platform. People can walk up the slight incline onto the station and walk straight onto the train. An immense number of elderly people have complained to me about the difficulty they have getting on and off buses. That is one of the things that the people of Broken Hill do not want to do. They want to use the train.

If you cut any services to Broken Hill I think it is fair to warn you that you will receive a frosty welcome which will certainly highlight to the rest of Australia just what you have done to the people of Broken Hill and how you may have made them more isolated. Look at what they did when the Silver City Comet was taken off the rail line. The Silver City Comet used to run from Parkes to Broken Hill several times a week. The service was cut by the Greiner conservative government in New South Wales. The law‐abiding citizens of Ivanhoe, a small rural community, put their four‐wheel drive vehicles across the rail track and held up the train. When the train got to Broken Hill it was somehow commandeered and kept at the station. It was then placed in a museum. Anybody visiting Broken Hill for the next six years or so was told, `That's the Silver City Comet that got stolen off us. That's the service we lost.'

That is the sort of thing that they will do, and they will do it very vocally. They will certainly make sure the people of Australia know. If the government even puts at risk their Indian Pacific, their public transport, it will certainly be accused—quite rightly, I think—of neglecting the concerns and interests of remote Australia. As I said, it is remote Australia out there. It is the accessible outback. People there are working hard to overcome the difficulties of living in a remote area and the downturn in the mining sector. They are looking to improve their tourism potential—and they have plenty, believe me. The Brushmen of the Bush, some of the best artists in this country, are out at Broken Hill. There are probably more art galleries per square kilometre in Broken Hill than anywhere else in this country. This is because of the beauty of the place, the stunning grandeur and the fact that it evokes in these artistic characters such incredible dynamism and an ability to display and express what they see and what they feel.

A couple of years ago the Indian Pacific service dropped back to one a week. When the service was increased to the usual two there was a significant growth in the number of people who travelled. The tourism person out there, Neil McGarry, feels that the growth was primarily in relation to the running of the Indian Pacific. In evidence to the committee, he said:

The major marked increase we had in the use of trains by tourists visiting Broken Hill commenced when the second IP service was commenced in about 1993 or 1994. Once that second train was on the track it really improved our passenger performance out of that area.
He went on to say:
Most of our rail passengers are, however, out here on package tours. You have to understand that we have very well‐developed half‐day and day tour operations within Broken Hill and extended tours.
They were able to tell us of the actual breakdown of the market:
. . . something like 24 per cent of our overall New South Wales based market arrives in Broken Hill by the Indian Pacific or by train services.
In relation to our tourists from South Australia, about 14 per cent of all our visitors from South Australia use rail.
He wanted to repeat the position:
The historic position of Broken Hill has been—
this is the mayor, Peter Black—

and I have supported it both publicly and privately—that privatisation would lead to the re‐routing of the train in so far as Broken Hill on the rail corridor and the community it serves between Broken Hill and Parkes.
There has never been a long‐term guarantee.

That is what worries them greatly. There has never been a guarantee that there will be a long‐term continuation of the Indian Pacific ; there has been only talk of selling it off and having luxury trains. As I keep repeating, the Indian Pacific is a public transport for this community and others on that line. That never needs to be forgotten. By all means, upgrade it, but do not start talking about having an Indian Pacific that will compare with the Shinhansen in Japan, because that has access to the carriage of 57 million passengers each year. That is not the size of population that we are talking about in Broken Hill and in the west of this country. We are talking about services here that have—and must continue to have—a significant public transport component. I hope that people will oppose this bill for the sake of those communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman, Sen Dominic

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to speak on behalf of South Australian industry and those South Australians who work in the railways. Many rail workers and their families are watching with a great deal of concern as the Australian rail system is used as part of an ideological experiment. Yes, there can be no doubt that this is an experiment. There are no guarantees that selling AN and privatising the entire industry in due course will improve the employment circumstances or the future of rail.

SPEECH.PARA: The supporters of the sell-off cannot seem to explain how it will benefit the railway communities of my state, nor can they explain how it will benefit rail in the long term. The Port Augusta council supports the sale; yet I see no evidence that a private owner would maintain the Port Augusta workshops or keep AN employees in their jobs.

The Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill before us empowers two ministers to determine the fate of rail in Australia. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) are going to be in the position to determine what happens to any assets and what ultimately happens to Australian National itself. This Senate will be handing to these two ministers virtually total power over the Australian railway system. I say that we must not allow such an expansion of the executive power which will limit our ability to stand up for the people who elected us. This legislation empowers the ministers to override existing legislation and prevents the full use of the Senate's powers of disallowance.

The Brew report showed us how commercial considerations can be used as an excuse to hide the government's activities from the public. This process must be transparent—too many people's futures depend on it. The Senate references inquiry, established by Labor, into the Brew report and the future of Commonwealth involvement in rail made some very important observations and findings.

The inquiry discovered that, whilst the Brew report had provided adequate analysis of the individual businesses that make up AN, it did not and could not provide a guide or framework to the future development of rail in this nation. Indeed, Labor is of the view that no major decisions can be made about the development of the rail industry unless there is a comprehensive analysis of the whole sector. Further, Labor believes, as did the Senate inquiry, that there must be a land transport policy framework that takes into account all factors which relate to the use of road and rail. There must be a long‐term approach to take into account the possible investment that may occur as well as the needs of agricultural, transportation and manufacturing industry.

On 24 November, the government launched its rail reform package but, despite the claim that this was a $2 billion reform measure, only $122 million was actually new money. In the style of the South Australian Olsen Liberal government, we see the Howard government announcing spending that has already been announced. The inquiry was critical of this package. On top of the limited financial support for rail there were also a number of other concerns that the inquiry had. These include issues relating to the funding for the upgrading of track and to the value of the Commonwealth's rail assets.

The inquiry also found that National Rail should not be sold in any event prior to the end of the National Rail agreement. But this is clearly a risk with this government's current policy and mentality. In the last budget there was a further cut of $80 million over four years for the proposed Track Authority. This organisation was already going to begin life without enough funds to fulfil its role as the guardian of our basic rail infrastructure. Labor was committed to giving $370 million to Track Australia; the coalition have cut that expenditure to $175 million.

The government has not told us how much AN is going to bring, if it is sold. The lack of understanding of what the sale actually means is concerning. The myths that are being created about what it will do for rail are even more concerning. Selling AN is not a fix for rail in Australia, particularly in the current environment.

We can understand the despair of some workers about the instability of their jobs and their kids' futures that leads them to support a sale. No-one can blame workers for looking towards a positive development in rail, but the government is not offering positive changes with this legislation. The Shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Tanner, attempted to ensure that the parliament maintain some control over this process. In his amendment at the second reading stage, Labor indicated the conditions under which rail policy and this debate must be developed. We will again move this amendment in the Senate. Those conditions are as follows.

Firstly, and as I previously mentioned, we want to see coherent policy which takes into account the entire rail industry and infrastructure. Secondly, we want to see agreements with the state governments involved about the future of their respective rail industries and the role that they will play in rail. Thirdly, we want to see a labour market adjustment program for displaced AN workers and a better regional adjustment package. A measly $20 million is just not enough. Fourthly, Labor wants the maintenance of all existing passenger server operations, as well as travel concessions. The community must not suffer with the loss of services or increased unfairness when it comes to public transport costs.

Fifthly, we want the government to live up to its recent rhetoric about apprenticeships and ensure that all apprentices continue to be employed, at least until the end of their contracts. Sixthly, we want the South Australian and Tasmanian governments to establish safety and regulatory arrangements for the rail industry. Seventhly, we want all employees who have left AN due to work related illness or injury since the announcement of the rail package last year to be offered redundancy pay.

Finally, Labor wants AN to ensure that the superannuation arrangements are fair for workers who are part of an AN principal scheme. We want to see any surplus in the scheme distributed to workers and not paid to the government. This scheme does not have full vesting of employer contributions. Workers are treated as though they have resigned, even though they have been compulsorily retrenched. These are the things that greatly concern us about the sale and its immediate impact on jobs and rail infrastructure.

Another area of particular concern to Labor relates to the track authority, as was originally proposed by Labor in government but which has also been a part of the government's policy. The importance of this matter is evidenced by Labor's attempt to amend the bill to ensure the development of an effective track authority. We will continue with our pursuit of these guarantees during the committee stage.

The sale of AN is supposed to see the transfer of interstate mainland track to the track authority. However, the bill does not ensure that this happens. We assume that the new authority is to be established soon, but the bill does not prevent the sale of interstate mainland track, nor does it even define what interstate mainland track is. The public must be assured that the major lines that will be the basis of economic development are protected from the most unsatisfactory possibility of private ownership.

The fact is that much of rail infrastructure should be protected from the sell‐off process. An obvious situation is with the Alice Springs to Tarcoola line, which will be an essential part of a future Alice Springs to Darwin rail line. But there are other important lines which must be protected—the Whyalla to Port Augusta line, which is essential to BHP's steel operation, and national rail's steel freight business. This line will be essential to the development of new industries in Whyalla, and as a South Australian I know how important this transport option is to the development of potential new industries in the Spencer Gulf region and beyond. There are other South Australian lines that must be protected as well.

So Labor finds itself in a position where it cannot support the passage of this bill. It does not address the concerns of the communities and workers concerned. It does not give a vision for rail in Australia. It does not even come close. We are in a situation where the planning by the government has not been done. Labor has given the minister plenty of opportunity to expand the investigation into the rail industry, but he has chosen to do nothing. He has not even been to visit the workers in Port Augusta, where his decisions will most probably have the greatest single effect on a community.

We want security for workers. We want continuity for apprentices. We want proper support for regional Australia, not pocket money. We want people to be at the centre of this decision, not blind ideology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are not willing advocates of the privatisation of public assets. We have been staunch critics of the ideological bias which has blindly driven the privatisation agenda in Australia. For more than a decade, Labor and the coalition have voted together—time and again—to sell‐off, contract out and downgrade public sector assets and services.

SPEECH.PARA: By contrast, we have stuck to our principles and consistently voted against privatisations which have not demonstrated a clear, net, long-term public benefit. We have opposed the sale of contracting out of community services, of hospitals and of power and water services. We voted against the sale of Qantas. We voted against the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We voted against the sale of Telstra. We voted against these privatisations because they were not in the public interest.

One of the key problems, of which we have been repeatedly critical, is that Australian governments, both state and federal, have forged ahead with privatisation with very little consideration given to the alternatives or to the medium‐ to long-term community and economic consequences. Another strong concern of ours has been the consistent underpricing of public assets. Australia has lost billions in the process of sale which has undervalued their assets. Underpricing of public assets has been one of the hallmarks of privatisation in Australia. It happened with the Commonwealth Bank, with Qantas and with the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. What it has meant is that a relatively small number of people, the new owners, have made windfall gains at the expense of all the taxpayers of Australia.

A third concern of ours is the risk which privatisation means for community service obligations. These are genuine concerns which must be addressed and which we would like to see dealt with in this bill. The Democrats reject the economic rationalist mind‐set. This is a mind‐set which sees no value in the community, in society, and where there is no need for social or community interests to be upheld or protected by governments. The world of the economic rationalist is one in which governments only exist to deregulate, privatise and withdraw.

The Democrats are not, however, opposed to greater efficiency in the delivery of services. Nor are we opposed to privatisation where it delivers real social and long-term economic benefits. What we are opposed to is seeing privatisation as a goal in itself. It is a fundamental flaw to see privatisation as inherently a good thing. Privatisation is simply a means to an end—that is to say, it is only appropriate when it furthers the public interest.

What we first need to decide is what sort of social and economic benefits and services we want to deliver to the community—that is, we must define the public interest and then we must carefully explore whether or not privatisation will deliver those benefits and services. It is for this reason that my colleague and fellow Democrat Senator John Woodley, when he chaired the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee inquiry into the Brew report and the continuing role of the Commonwealth in the Australian rail industry, said about privatisation that he felt it contributed to the corporatisation of Australia.

In the case of the Australian National Railways Commission we believe there is a case to be made for privatisation. When previously in government, the Labor Party presided over the slow and steady decline of our rail industry and the decline of AN. I am aware that there were enthusiasts for rail within the then government but they did not have the ear of the Treasurer or of the cabinet and ultimately rail continued to decline. As a consequence, the ALP effectively destroyed AN during their term in government and desperate changes are unfortunately needed.

The situation is now dire. Morale in AN is at an all-time low and good managers have disappeared because governments have insisted on treating rail as a business rather than as a service—what is more, as a short‐term business. They have convinced everyone that debt levels are high. Yes, the cost is high, but so it is for schools, hospitals, roads and all our other services. The way in which rail is structured and managed has meant that debt is indeed now an issue.

AN has effectively been destroyed and driven into the ground. Both this and the former government are responsible. In our view it has been broken, and, like Humpty Dumpty, the pieces cannot be put together again. Clearly, therefore, something needs to be urgently done. Clearly, a revitalisation of rail is still needed—on economic grounds, on environmental grounds and on community grounds. Because of the state AN is in now, we believe that the sale of some of AN's assets may be warranted—where an injection of capital funds and managerial expertise can provide a much needed boost, especially if jobs are to be safeguarded and especially if rail is to start to grow at the expense of the road.

This is a position that we are not alone in reaching. The Public Transport Union have made it clear that they want AN sold. Many of the workers at AN have made it clear that they want AN sold. Key rail organisations, in particular Rail 2000 and the Australian Railways Association, have made it clear that they want AN sold. They have accepted that the way AN is and the way it is managed and is funded will mean its continued decline unless it is sold.

For these reasons, the Democrats are therefore prepared to consider a sale, but we can only support a sale that is clearly in the public interest and will deliver a net economic and community benefit. I have said there is a rationale for the sale, because the alternative that this government has threatened us with is complete closure and failure of the rail network. However, the government has attempted to rush through a sale without properly working through the issues, engaging in adequate consultation or establishing an appropriate framework for the industry. It is an exceptionally complex issue—and all of us in this chamber understand that—but the government has not addressed the complexity in a manner which gives any of us confidence.

This is a government which has sought to legislate in terms of rail by press release rather than through the parliament. The ridiculous sale timetable that has resulted tells the story—and we are dealing with such a complex issue—when expressions of interest closed in mid‐April. That is about two months ago. The sale timetable left little time for prospective buyers to lodge suitably detailed and thought through submissions. It put them under undue stress.

Final offers had to be lodged by early June, giving selected bidders only a few weeks to work on their submissions. We are talking here about submissions that involve very substantial amounts of money and very substantial commitments. One bidder, preferring to remain anonymous, was reported as saying that it was ridiculous to ask bidders to prepare adequate documentation in such a short space of time. It was neither commercial in its speed nor helpful to those who might be the salvation of our rail industry. Another person questioned why the sale was being rushed through when the new owner cannot and will not be operating on 1 July.

Then we come to the question of how government dealt with the sale. The sale bill was not tabled in the House of Representatives until 14 May 1997 after expressions of interest had been called for. It should have been tabled last session. The Senate has been put under undue pressure once again to try to deal with a bill with terrific ramifications in a very short space of time. If opposition parties had been given more and adequate time to examine clauses it could have avoided the need for getting an exemption from the cut‐off motion. It might have also resulted in far more cross-party support for fundamental reform.

It also needs to be pointed out that neither the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), nor the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) nor their representatives in the Senate have sought our opinion or bothered to consult directly with us. We, amongst the other six parties in the Senate, are responsible for the passage of legislation. How the government and this minister can expect to manage their legislation in the Senate when they do not consult with the parties concerned in advance of the legislation beats me. This minister makes a practice of this sort of approach.

Moreover, it was only recently that the government realised that complementary legislation had to be passed by the South Australian parliament. The South Australian bill is yet to be tabled in that parliament because they have to wait and see whether this bill is passed. As a consequence, the Senate is put under that pressure as well. This is not management; this is incompetence and such incompetence should be recorded.

The government has also approached rail reform more generally in an inadequately structured and inadequately planned fashion. Let us consider some of the issues. Firstly, the sale is being rushed through while key rail reforms, including establishment of a National Track Authority and including much needed funding for track upgrading, have been deferred. What does it say for a government, which should be dedicated to infrastructure development and jobs, when it has deferred both those issues?

A meagre $175 million over four years was promised by the government for upgrading of track, yet they announced that this had been deferred. In contrast, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics had recommended $3.2 billion over 20 years, not $175 million over four years. Such large expenditure is essential, especially if the interstate tracks in Victoria and New South Wales are to be upgraded to acceptable standards. This contrasts hugely with the approach to road, which easily gets billions of dollars expendi ture and on which the government has a fixation.

Another concern is the existing community service obligations—obligations which the government simply refuses to acknowledge. The AN interstate passenger services and the Tasmanian freight operations are, in our view, community service obligations—that is, they are loss making activities financed and funded from the budget. That is a common approach to all services of the government.

There is no guarantee that funding for subsidised fares will continue. In fact this government simply chooses to bury its head in the sand. When I asked the government on notice last year to provide me with details of all AN's community service obligations, they sent me a response saying that there are none. That is a very strange matter. I appreciate that the community service obligation has a particular meaning in legislation but, in the broader sense of those words, community service obligation is the obligation you have to the citizens of this country to provide an essential service, yet you do not do so.

Another concern with this bill is that it enables all the tracks to be sold. It is no good having that power and then saying that you do not intend to exercise that power. Frankly, the Senate would be most unwise to trust this government with such an approach. The government has said it will sell only the intrastate—that is, the South Australian and Tasmanian tracks—and not the interstate track, which is to be owned and managed by a new National Track Authority based in Adelaide. But what guarantee have we that this will occur and why does the bill not expressly say that? Why does the bill enable absolutely everything to be sold? Is it deliberate deceit? Is it an oversight? What is the reason for it?

The fact is that the tracks and associated infrastructure, such as terminals, are a natural monopoly and, in our view, should be retained in full public ownership. I am aware that last year Labor agreed to the lease of the airports—in my opinion to their shame, and against which we voted—which were also a natural monopoly. I hope this time they will look at the track in an entirely different fashion.

The Democrats are prepared to agree to a sale of some aspects of rail but conditions are required. We are happy for the government to redefine its role in rail, but we will not support a government seeking to abrogate its role. Government must take an active position on the future of rail and on the future of its land transport strategy, which it does not have.

Our amendments will guarantee that a National Track Authority is established and will be based in South Australia. Those amendments are a repeat, if you like, of the government's original commitments. The authority will own and manage the track and associated assets and it will be backed up by legislation guaranteeing that parliamentary approval will be required before those track and associated assets can be sold off. We will also be seeking a guarantee that desperately needed funding for track upgrading, as promised by the government, is restored.

We believe that the commencement date of the bill should be when the Commonwealth government has reached agreements with South Australia and Tasmania on funding assistance for development of their rail infrastructures. We believe that the bill should provide a labour market adjustment program for displaced AN workers. Some of these, of course, are issues that Labor has advanced. We believe that the South Australian and Tasmanian governments should put in place safety and regulatory arrangements for the rail industry before the transfers take place.

We believe that Australian National should demonstrate that all employees who have left since the announcement on 24 November 1996 not voluntarily but as a result of work related illness or injury should be offered redundancy payments. We believe that Australian National should alter the trust deed of the AN principal scheme to allow full vesting of employer contributions to all employees that have left or leave after 24 November 1996 and to ensure that appropriate adjustment payments are made to those who have already left AN's employment.

BREAK.PARA: We do not want to see a repetition of the Qantas scandal. We want to see that the employment and training of apprentices is guaranteed until completion of their apprenticeship contracts, and that should be a sale condition. We believe that existing passenger services and concession arrangements should be guaranteed for at least five years as a condition of sale. It is appropriate that the government ensures that, in the transition period, rail's customers are not left in the air whilst any private or public owners find their feet in the new conditions.

We propose that, rather than the sale, the government should consider a long‐term lease of the Tasrail and South Australian Freight tracks and associated infrastructure, but that, regardless of whether it is a sale or lease, the state governments should have the right of first refusal. They should have the right to make the decision as to whether they wish to run their own rail infrastructure and under what terms.

We believe that funding for track upgrading should be restored to the level promised by the government, which was $175 million over four years. We think that should be effective immediately. We would like the government to spend a great deal more, but we are not the government, so we can only ask them to spend what they have in fact agreed to spend.

We believe the government should agree to hold a public inquiry to get a cross‐party approach to this complex and vital issue and should table an integrated land transport strategy in both houses of parliament by 1 July 1998. You cannot progress rail unless you have a view on pricing, on access, on competition, on the integration of systems, on customer services, on community service obligations and so on. That requires government to produce a land transport strategy on economic, environmental and community grounds. We believe that the exemption of the bill from the Legislative Instruments Act 1997 should not go ahead. We think they should refer back to parliament.

Finally, I would like to speak briefly about the points raised by the Labor Party in its second reading amendment. Those points are good ones. They are ones the government must address, but we do not believe that they are good enough to delay the bill. We believe those points should be included in the bill where they can be, but they must not be used as a means to defer or delay the bill. We believe the concerns raised in the second reading amendment can be accommodated, whilst still passing the bill. We would make the commencement of the bill dependent on those issues being addressed by the government. Accordingly, with regret, whilst we agree with many of the points being made by Labor in the second reading amendment, we will be opposing it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Hundreds of thousands of people in Australia have, to their credit or even detriment, been workers for railways or the PMG's department, or both. I am one of those. I do not know how many there are, but quite a number of people that you meet have either worked for the railways or for the PMG's department in the last 40 years or so.

SPEECH.PARA: I do have to say that this matter has been a matter where I have had to put aside my emotional attachment, if you like, to the railways. This attachment is part of our family tradition. My grandfather happened to be the boiler attendant at the Finke on the early part of the track. I come from a railway family and was born in a railway town, Quorn in South Australia. It is no longer a railway town. It has not been for a considerable period of years, although there is a good tourist railway chugging along that neck of the woods. I recommend anybody to go on it. I have an attachment. I worked for some little time on the transcontinental railway in the 1950s. As I say, one needs to put aside the emotional attachment that one has if one is to make a decision and to contribute to this legislative debate. I hope that, to the extent that I am able, I have done that.

A decision made by the previous government in 1993 to allow all of AN's interstate freight business to be transferred to the National Railways Commission, I believe, put the Australian National Railways Commission on the skids. The review of the Australian National Railways Commission and the National Rail Corporation in 1996, out of which came the Brew report, pointed to the extremely serious financial and operational position of ANR and, to a lesser extent, that of NRC. Brew reported that the position of ANR was so serious as to warrant shutting down significant parts of the enterprise.

In respect of this particular matter, I here interpolate that, whilst my primary interest is in the state of Tasmania, I nonetheless feel I have an obligation to South Australians and, indeed, Western Australians. In relation to Tasmania, the Brew report went so far as to suggest that, if short‐line operators could not be found, the operation should be totally closed down. It would seem to me that successive governments have failed to provide an efficient and viable rail system.

In addition, the deregulation of freight transport in Tasmania has seen a substantial drop in the tonnages on Tasrail. Under Commonwealth government ownership, there has been a huge decline of employment in Tasrail; it is down now to 240 people. This is a far cry from the time when there were thriving workshops in northern Tasmania. I knew quite a few people in the workshops in northern Tasmania; in fact, in the days of the Trades Hall and the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, I eventually got the ARU back into the fold. There were very significant contributions made both in southern Tasmania, and in the north and the north-west coast. I remember very fondly one of those unionists who was the among those who were the backbone of the Devonport Trades and Labour Council.

The view of the Tasmanian government clearly is that the sale of Australian National should proceed. That also is the view of those unionists with whom I have spoken and—I am quite well aware of this fact—it particularly is the view of a number of unionists who are working in South Australia.

I would not, and will not, support this bill, unless a number of issues relating to Tasrail employees and rail infrastructure are resolved. I hope that they have come to that resolution in the last week; as I understand it, they are nearing that situation now. I have been given certain undertakings and assurances by the government in this regard. My concerns are that, should the sale of Australian National proceed, the Commonwealth should face up to its obligations in regard to all Tasrail employees. It should ensure that the track is left in good condition, and that environmental remediation be undertaken.

One of the outstanding matters which will affect some AN employees relates to superannuation. This has been referred to, I think, by almost every speaker who has spoken in the bill's second reading debate. In this respect, alterations need to be made to the trust deed of the AN principal scheme to enable full vesting of employer contributions. Otherwise, some employees facing redundancy will be severely financially disadvantaged. I am advised that the ANR Commission is to consider this matter at its meeting this week.

Most importantly, I hope that the proposed privatisation of AN will result in an efficient, competitive, dynamic and reliable rail system in Tasmania and South Australia. I am aware of the fact that it is the view of persons who know the situation intimately in Tasmania that the Tasmanian railways are in danger of imploding. It is of vital importance that rail transport continue as an option in Tasmania for Tasmanian businesses. It is suggested that, if this bill is not accepted and does not go ahead, the outlook is very, very grim indeed.

I am opposed to the sale of public monopoly assets. But, of course, the question of monopoly does not arise in respect of AN because there is competition—road competition and sea competition—from the north-west coast through to southern Tasmania. That is not often adverted to. In fact, the continuance of rail in Tasmania, in my view, is absolutely vital for the future development of the state and for the future alleviation of the burden on the Tasmanian roads system.

A number of major investments are being considered in the mining and manufacturing industries in Tasmania which may well rely on the existing rail infrastructure and an efficient operating rail system, which private enterprise appears to offer—well, that is what they are saying. It is vital for the development of an integrated sea, road and rail transport system to service the needs of the Tasmanian community. Several potential operators have already indicated that there is the potential to increase the amount of goods carried on rail and to move tonnage off the road system. As we from Tasmania all know, the Emu Bay railway, operating in the west and north‐west of Tasmania, has demonstrated that the rail system can be operated efficiently in Tasmania for the benefit of industry.

A further area for development is tourism—and, of course, tourism is vital to Tasmania. A number of operators conduct historical tours, including the Tasmanian Railway Preservation Society operating in the Derwent Valley. They are, of course, seeking to improve these tourist services, and I would be very pleased to see a boost along for those particular services.

For all the reasons that I have given, I am keen that an efficient, competitive, dynamic and reliable system be maintained both for my state and for the operation in South Australia. If the sale of AN as proposed in this bill is the only way to achieve this, provided the Commonwealth meets its obligations, including its obligations to existing employees, and ensures the good condition of track and rolling stock assets, I am inclined to support the second reading stage of this measure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Are you speaking briefly?
—As briefly as you do, my friend.
—Well, you're the ones who want the legislation through.

—We do. I think there are a couple of things that need to be said. Firstly, I want to thank all the speakers who have participated in the debate. I did not have the privilege of hearing them all directly in the chamber, except for Senator Harradine, but I did find Senator Harradine's comments very sympathetic, particularly to the workers, and very understanding of the difficulty that would be faced by the workers and those who hope to rely on efficient rail services, particularly in Tasmania and South Australia, if this legislation does not go ahead.

BREAK.PARA: I was particularly observant of the fact that Senator Harradine had consulted because, in many respects, it has been very puzzling to me to hear statements made by politicians claiming that they know what the workers think or that they have a view on the subject or that somehow they have not had enough time to form a view on the subject when clearly Senator Harradine, with all his manifold responsibilities, is able to consult and to ascertain what the true position is.

As I understand it, the Democrats are claiming that they have not had sufficient time to consult on the matter. This bill was introduced into the House of Representatives some six weeks ago. It was foreshadowed as long ago as last November. An inquiry into the sale has been before the relevant Senate reference committee. That is what I think makes very hollow claims by people like the Greens and Senator Brown that there has been a lack of consultation with the workers. The Greens did not attend any of the reference committee hearings nor have they contacted by letter or by phone the minister for transport in Tasmania or I suspect the minister for transport in this place regarding the future of Tasrail.

As far as the Democrats making similar complaints, we know there have been very extensive representations made by the workers. There is one letter that I thought summarised the way in which this exercise has proceeded. It is addressed to senators and ministers, it is dated 28 June and it is signed. It reads:

As an employee of Australian National, I wish to register my disgust at the proposed blockage of the sale by Labor and Democrat parties. I have been trying to register my disgust with these parties for the last two weeks, both state and federal, but have been fobbed off each time. The two Democrat senators offices have said they don't handle this, talk to Senator Woolly [sic] in Queensland or Andrew Murray in Perth. Meg Lees office was a bit understanding, would pass my concern on to Senator Woolly [sic]. Stott-Despoja's office wasn't interested at all and told me to talk to Andrew Murray. I have twice rung her office to voice my concern. Both times I was told to talk to someone else. I have spoken to Lindsay Tanner's office in Melbourne but got little response from them as well. I have tried Mike Wran's office as well and was told someone will call back.
Labor in this state have said workers don't want the sale to go ahead, but who have they talked to because, believe me, no-one has bothered to talk to me or my co‐workers.

That I think is pretty typical of the response that has emerged from the workers themselves. For those who purport to have the workers' interests in mind, I did run through this in the Senate last week. It is quite clear that a number of the leading spokesmen, including the state secretary of the Public Transport Union, have warned that any delay to the sale would cause unneeded hardship and grief for the workers. Len Scharenberg of the Australian Workers Union was interviewed after the visit of Lindsay Tanner to Port Augusta. Again, I made it clear in the Senate what he thought of the outcome of that visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least he's been there; the minister for transport hasn't.

—The trouble is they wanted Mr Beazley to go there, but Mr Beazley would not go there. Instead he muzzled Mr Tanner. One is entitled to suspect that Mr Tanner himself is a bit perplexed as to why he has been giving riding instructions to oppose this sale.
—Have you been there?

—No, I do not have direct responsibility. I have been there in the past but not in regard to this issue. The important thing is that the people in Port Augusta in particular, the residents of South Australia in general and the residents of Tasmania simply cannot comprehend why those who purport to be close to the workers are not consulting with the workers and are doing something that is quite inimical to the workers' interests.

BREAK.PARA: So I think that has now been flushed out. It is quite clear what the workers' view is. They are very keen to see this legislation go ahead. I note what Senator Harradine said about various undertakings and assurances. I do not have personal knowledge of those, but I assume that those negotiations have been proceeding and that he is justified in having confidence that the meeting of the ANR Commission later this week will endorse the full vesting of employer contributions. On that basis, the concerns that have been legitimately expressed will be resolved. Then we are left, essentially, with the question of whether or not this is going to salvage an industry which clearly has been going backwards as a result of inaction over recent years.

I do not think I need to add any more to the debate. Hopefully, I have demonstrated that not only are the arguments very compelling but those who purport to oppose them are not consulting the workers and, therefore, are not representing their interests. The truth of the matter is that the workers themselves want the sale to go ahead. The future for those workers themselves does depend on the sale and the injection of private sector enterprise and investment.

I think we all share Senator Harradine's aspiration for an efficient, competitive, dynamic and, obviously, successful rail service. Again, I think one could only agree that the outlook would be very grim indeed if it did not go ahead. In fact, all of the organisations and the workers themselves who are calling for the sale to proceed are under no illusions about what their prospects would be if it did not. So, on that basis, I trust that we will be able to see this bill through the parliament tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through the chair, Senator Alston, I suggest you do not use that sort of tone with me. This bill should have been dealt with in the next session. We do not have loads of ministers and departmental advisers sitting around in the background to assist us. SPEECH.PARA: Through the chair, Senator Alston, fortunately that is typical of only some of your ministry. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise again to all parties within the Senate for the late circulation of these amendments. Amendment No. 1 is quite self‐explanatory, I think. It is an attempt to broaden the consideration by government of a number of issues which we think are essential to the process.

My understanding, Minister, is that some of that process is already under way and it merely formalises what we would regard as good labour practice in those instances.
