The fourth part of the amendment relates to those employees who have ceased to be employees of the commission since the announcement on 24 November 1996, not voluntarily but as a result of work related illness or injury. We believe that they should be included in a redundancy package.

The last amendment says that the trust deed of the Australian National principal scheme should have been altered `to allow full vesting of employer contributions to all employees who cease to be employees of the Commission or who have ceased to be employees of the Commission since 24 November 1996 . . . '

You will recognise in there some of the elements of Labor's second reading amendment. Primarily, I would summarise that amendment as attempting to draw together the strands of taking care of the people and taking care of the state‐Commonwealth relationships. I therefore commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the advice of the committee, now having had the opportunity to examine the remainder of the Democrat amendments, the opposition will be supporting all of the remaining Democrat amendments. We will also be supporting the amended amendment circulated by Senator Brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not agree with these amendments. The first part relating to an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states of South Australia and Tasmania is simply far too broad. Our commitment is to contribute in a financial sense to interstate arrangements but there is no commitment to provide funds in respect of intrastate infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as (b) is concerned, it is couched in very wide terms, so `a' labour market adjustment program really tells you nothing and you always have the nightmare of deciding precisely when it would come into effect or who makes the judgment.

The same goes, I think, for the states of South Australia and Tasmania enacting legislation. As far as `all persons who cease to be employees' being offered a redundancy payment is concerned, that again is something that is a matter for the commission, and it has indicated, I think, sympathy for that approach.Similarly, with the superannuation `full vesting of employer contributions', that is a matter for the board.

But the principal concern has to be (1A)(a). We are committed to providing $20 million by way of a regional adjustment package to both South Australia and Tasmania. This effectively calls for us to go beyond that, and that simply cannot take place. But it would certainly be premature, given that the actual impact in regions is not yet clear and it is really asking for a blank cheque.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech on the second reading I did refer to this question of the superannuation area—the problem that has been exercising the minds of a number of people, particularly those acting on behalf of employees affected. This amendment at part (e) is really saying that the schedules:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . commence on the day after the day, or the later of the days, on which the Minister causes to be laid before Houses of the Parliament evidence that:

(e) the trust deed of the Australian National Principal Scheme has been altered to allow full vesting of employer contributions to all employees who cease to be employees of the Commission or have ceased to be employees of the Commission since 24 November 1996 and to ensure that appropriate adjustment payments are made to persons who ceased to be employee of the Commission before 24 November 1996.

I really feel that the Senate is owed by the government some indication in respect of that particular matter. It has been a matter that has been the subject of discussions and consultations. The area of the major discussions affects only a few employees. So far as Tasmania is concerned, I think only about seven or eight employees are concerned. I do feel that the committee would appreciate a more fulsome indication by the government as to what is likely to happen. I suppose it cannot say what the commission is going to do, but as I understand it the commission is going to consider this matter at its meeting this week.

I know that the government may not be able, strictly speaking, to speak on behalf of the commission. Nevertheless, it ought to have a fairly good idea as to what the commission is likely to do and it ought to be able to tell the committee what is likely to occur. So I ask the minister, on behalf of the government, to detail the information he has. That information ought to be placed before this committee, given the concerns that have been expressed right around the chamber on this particular issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are all in heated agreement on the approach that ought to be adopted here. It is certainly the government's desire and expectation that the commission—which is scheduled to meet this week—should act in those terms. We have every reason to believe that they will, so we would be both very surprised and disappointed if they did not. I make it clear, as strongly as I can, that that is what we would like them to do. We think it is the proper thing to do. We believe that they share that view and that they will make a formal and sympathetic decision later this week to give effect to the spirit of that amendment.

—As it is obvious that we will not be voting on the bill by 7 o'clock, I am absolutely forced to ask the minister: apart from being surprised and disappointed should the commission take that decision, what will the government do?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably a little premature—
—We have our means!

—Of making you pay, not just talk. I have not got formal instructions on that, as we used to say at the bar. But as I understand it, you would need an approval from the Treasurer, and there may be some formal power of direction, but I am not sure about that. Indeed, if it is like the power of direction that is contained in a few other GBEs, then I think there is probably a serious reluctance about the use of it.
—That is the reason I asked. Telecom is just ignoring the COT cases.
—Indeed. I think we have both made our positions very clear on that one.
—Surprised and disappointed about that?

—Not surprised, no. From the government's point of view, if it were to come to that, I am sure that we would then explore all other avenues reasonably open to us to make sure that what I think is the strong wish of all parties in the chamber is acceded to. Can I be any more precise than that?
—That'll do.
—Amendment Nos 3, 4 and 5 appear to be consequential on amendment No. 1. That having been negatived, I assume that Senator Murray will not be proceeding with amendment Nos 3, 4 and 5.
—That is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 6 (after line 12), after subsection 67AD(3), insert:

(3A) Without limiting the generality of subsections (l), (2) and (3), the Minister for Finance must, by written notice given to the Commission, give the following directions in respect of the assets of the operations of the Commission within the State of Tasmania (Tasrail):

that before being offered for sale or transfer to any other party, the assets of Tasrail must first be offered for transfer to the State of Tasmania and the offer must not include any debts accumulated by Tasrail prior to the transfer.

This amendment deletes proposed subsection A and simply leaves subsection B. This means that, in effect, the offer would be made to the Tasmanian government before a general offer for public sale to the private sector of Tasrail. That offer, moreover, would be on the same terms as is proposed to the private sector so that the Tasmanian government could consider taking back ownership of Tasrail and that ownership would be free of debt and encumbrance.

It is a very important prospect for Tasmania. In Tasmania, both the government and the Labor opposition have not, to date, been keen to take back the ownership of Tasrail. Part of the problem there has been the prospect of the indebtedness and the need for continuing capital investment. But if the debt is taken away from Tasrail, on the figures I have—which show a $22 million income and outgo for the last year—there would be a further $5 million income over outgo, because the servicing of the debt would no longer be required. In other words, we have then a profitable concern with a considerable transfer of moneys from servicing debt to upgrading rolling stock and line. This makes it a very much more attractive proposition.

We believe that at least the offer should be made to the Tasmanian government first. I know the government will be considering taking on Tasrail with the ability it has to look at the wider public interest. If that fails, this amendment still allows for the government to then proceed to offer Tasrail to the private sector. So there it is: an offer to the Tasmanian government, then the possibility of private sector sale if that is not successful.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government cannot support this amendment. The state government in Tasmania have made their position emphatically clear. It certainly would not in any shape or form fit in with the approach they wish to pursue. They have seen what happens when there is government ownership and involvement and they are very keen indeed to have the private sector take its turn. There is no way this could work therefore we are opposed to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —On that matter: that was presuming that Tasrail was going to revert to Tasmanian government ownership with the debt encumbrance and certainly not be transferred back to Tasmania, as this amendment would have it. Whatever the advisers might say about this, the fact is that the Greens, who hold the balance of power in Tasmania, are very strongly in favour of this. They are negotiating with the government. The government has not closed the door. The opportunity needs to be made available for this offer to be taken up or turned down by the Tasmanian government in light of this amendment, which has not been discussed in its final form with the Tasmanian government, passing the Senate. It would not get in the way of a sale to private enterprise if Tasmania turned down that option, but that option should be there. The government ought to offer that option. I am hoping to convince the committee that that offer ought to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that we are handing to Tasmania the option of Tasrail in a profitable circumstance, not in a money losing circumstance. That is what the government intends to do as far as private enterprise is concerned. In this situation, the Tasmanian government would take Tasrail and it would be able to put its profits in coming years of around $5 million—and I am being conservative in my estimate—into the continuing upgrade of the rail system and the rolling stock which has been under way for some years now.

If the Tasmanian government turns down that offer then it can go for sale to private enterprise. It is a two‐step option. If the minister believes that the Tasmanian government is not going to entertain this option then he should have no fear of it. In light of the amendment as it stands and the work that has been done to develop this option for Tasman ia, I recommend strongly to the committee that it should be made.

I reiterate that it is a small system. It carries 16 per cent of the freight in Tasmania. It is basically a carrier of the resource extraction industries in Tasmania, but it is also important to small business. It is more important than ever as the shipping facilities are concentrated on the northern seaboard of Tasmania. A lot of the shipping that was once done out of Hobart is now being done out of the northern ports and therefore depends on either road or rail traffic. This rail option should be available in public ownership as a profitable enterprise, in the terms of this amendment.

I am also concerned that the track kilometerage be kept as is because there are sunrise options for the use of that track. In this age Tasmania's service industry, small businesses and design based industries are those which are providing the jobs and creating the economic stimulus in Tasmania. The old resource extraction industries are sadly losing jobs and are no longer the prospect for Tasmania that they were.

Tasrail is critical to the design of a different future for Tasmania. Tasrail in the hands of government becomes an instrument for redesigning Tasmania's away from the old age of hydro-industrialisation and job shedding heavy industry and towards the range of small business and sunrise industries of the future. Before the dinner suspension I spoke about the great mistake that was made when the Abt railway on the west coast was closed and how a consortium of people is now trying to raise $20 million to bring that railway back into being. Here we have the prospect of the whole of Tasrail being sold for $20 million, according to the lowest valuation.

I am underlining the importance of giving the Tasmanian government this option to think about before we sell Tasrail across to private enterprise. We should not repeat the mistakes of the past but make Tasrail an option for the implementation of the prospective alternative industries that Tasmania has for the future, and as a profitable concern. In this legislation the government is offering it for sale as a profitable concern. Let us give it back to the people of Tasmania as a profitable concern to upgrade the rolling stock and upgrade and realign the track to continue this as a profit making, stable employer and a fundamental part of Tasmania's strategic design for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support Senator Brown's amended amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for the record, the Tasmanian government are very much aware of this option. They considered it many weeks ago. There is nothing new in this last minute exercise on the part of Senator Brown. They do not regard it as profitable if you excise the debt. The fact is that the track cannot be ripped up or closed down. If that were to occur then the ownership reverts to the state. Expressions of interest were called for in April. The final bids are due in next month. The due diligence process is well under way. To somehow rip all that up at the last minute and go down what is absolutely a blind gulch or dry gulch—
—Dry gulch.

—Dry gulch. That would be worse than doing nothing. It would be to throw the whole process into disarray. I simply repeat that there is no basis on which the Tasmanian government is interested in pursuing matters of which they have been acutely aware for many months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The government can get itself into difficulties by pre-empting the passage of legislation through this parliament, but that is its fault. The Senate cannot be coerced by the fact that the government has decided that on the basis that it might get legislation through here it has proceeded towards the implementation of the outcome of that legislation as it wants it to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to the business of the Tasmanian government having turned this down. I say that they have not. But even if they have, let me point out the reality of politics in Tasmania. The Labor Party and the Greens have the ability to put legislation through the Tasmanian parliament if that is necessary. That puts the Tasmanian government in a very different situation. It does not, as a minority government, have the ability to take a cavalier approach to dismissing the sale, the acquiring of Tasrail in a profitable circumstance. It simply cannot do that. I can tell you that if we pass this amendment there will be legislation in the Tasmanian parliament to have it adopted. That will put the heat on the Tasmanian government.

So the acceptance or otherwise of this offer in Tasmania is a long way from being a matter of dismissal by the government of the day, even if it did decide in the wake of an amendment here that that was its option. I put it to the Senate that we should allow this option. If the Tasmanian parliament turns it down, if the Tasmanian government is so short-sighted as to turn it down, so be it. Then we move over to the sale to private enterprise option, which is the government's base motive here.

In the meantime, let us put it back to the Tasmanian government and, indeed, to the Tasmanian parliament whether or not it will take Tasrail as a profitable enterprise with all the prospects that it has in front of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to pick up the minister on some of the statements he made about the Tasmanian government not regarding the potential profitability for Tasrail without the debt. It is interesting that, even if there were a sale with something like a $20 million price tag, anyone would consider it profitable or try to sell it if what the government is saying is that the Tasmanian government does not regard it as potentially profitable.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a rather odd thing to say, one would think, unless the government is planning to pay someone to take Tasrail away. It is potentially profitable if you put it on the market and expect at least $20 million. I do not know whether they are intending to run it down or would run it down if they were in that situation. I would like to think no government would do that with public property.
The minister also made an interesting statement about leading us down a blind—I do not know what the word was; was it gulch or gully?

TALK.START.PARA: —Dry gulch—a well-known expression in B‐grade American westerns.

—If it has all been canvassed before, how could it be a blind gully or alley? Has that not actually been canvassed? This is very interesting: either it has been fully canvassed or it is a blind alley. It cannot be both at the same time. So what is it? Have the figures been done? What proof can you provide to us that the Tasmanian government was offered Tasrail without the debts accumulated?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am assured that the Tasmanian government regards the current state of AN as unprofitable, and that is without the debt. On that basis, they are not interested in pursuing the proposal that is contained in this amendment. I am not in a position to provide you with calculations. If that is their position, then clearly this approach is a waste of time, and that is what I mean by a dry gulch or blind alley or whatever other expression can be invoked. I should also add that I am advised that the minister has quoted the shadow minister in Tasmania as being in support of these proposals. In other words, there is no basis on which the Greens would have the balance of power in order to achieve the legislation that they somehow envisage.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Schedule 1, item 1, page 6 (after line 12), after section 67AD, insert:
The Commission must not sell or transfer any asset of the Commission unless it is a condition of the sale that:

PARA.TAB: (a) the employment training of any apprentices affected by the proposed sale or transfer are to be continued until the completion of their apprenticeship; and
(b) any existing passenger services and concession arrangements affected by the proposed sale or transfer are to be continued for not less than 5 years after the date of sale or transfer.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 1, page 6 (after line 12), after subsection 67AD(3), insert:

(3A) Without limiting the generality of subsections (1), (2) and (3), the Minister for Finance must, by written notice given to the Commission, direct that no sale or transfer of assets located within a State may occur unless the assets have first been offered for transfer to the relevant State.

Amendment No. 9, the first of these two amendments, is to take care of two areas when the conditions of sale or transfer are implemented. The first of those conditions is that the employment training of any apprentices affected by the proposed sale or transfer is to be continued until the completion of the apprenticeship. Minister, you would have been aware of the furore that accompanied the Qantas situation with apprentices. This seeks to avoid such a circumstance where any new employer, or even an old employer, could discontinue an apprenticeship contract.

The second part of that amendment refers to existing passenger services and concession arrangements affected by the proposed sale or transfer to be continued for not less than five years after the date of sale or transfer. We recognise that that would impose a cost on government. We have not been able to do the costings to establish exactly what it is. But we are of the opinion that any private or public owner to whom sale or transfer has been made may struggle for a while to find their feet in terms of exactly how they will run the service and exactly how they will operate the service. Consequently, we think that existing customers, existing citizens serviced by AN, should continue to be looked after. So that is the purpose of the second part of amendment No. 9.

The purpose of the amendment styled 3A, on sheet 578, is to ensure that the right of first refusal is offered to any state, prior to the transfer or sale of any assets. In a sense, that mirrors but widens to all of Australia the intention of Senator Brown's amendment, which is simply to ensure that public ownership can be contemplated by states where their parliaments are of the opinion that that is appropriate. I need say no more than that, I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the genuine nature of Senator Murray's amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997. My purpose in rising very briefly tonight is to emphasise the need to get a resolution from both Houses, if amendments are going to be necessary, before the end of this week.

SPEECH.PARA: I think few people really appreciate the run-down nature of the Tasmanian rail component of the Australian National Railways package. There is a degree of urgency. The staff levels are such that in many areas, in terms of the complement of people who are now running that service in Tasmania, there are specialist skills missing. If this drags on, I submit there may not be a railway to sell. The down‐sliding and degrading of operations are such that it is a major concern.

In our state, of course, the Tasmanian railways are the major hauliers of bulk products—logs, cement, coal, and all those sorts of things—and our roads are just not up to that standard. So, while people might have agendas as to who should own what and what should happen, I would submit that time is of the urgency. While often in this chamber bluff and counter-bluff is part of the showmanship, part of the attempt to win, I would say that, if we want a railway in our state, we must make sure that we do not delay it too long, otherwise events might overtake us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I would be very interested to hear what the government has to say about these particular amendments. I think I should sit down and, therefore, invite the government to respond.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that invitation. As far as the Deomcrats' second amendment is concerned, for all the reasons that I advanced in relation to Senator Brown's amendment, together with the fact that this goes further—in other words, it really requires a direction in respect of the sale of any assets, not just the bulk quantity of assets, and it is also located within a state so it is more specific—it is not acceptable to either government, on my advice.

BREAK.PARA: As far as Senator Murray's amendment 9(a) is concerned, a working party has been formed to oversee the ongoing management of apprentices. Also, direct contact has been initiated with various group training schemes to identify alternative employment opportunities for apprentices. The new owner is expected to employ some, and there are a number of other employers and organisations who have indicated a willingness to take over the training of additional apprentices. I can assure the Senate that both Commonwealth and state governments will be seeking to ensure that young people who have not completed their apprenticeships will not be disadvantaged by the sale.

In respect of 9(b), passenger services and concessions, the sale of the passenger business to inject private sector expertise is expected to lower costs, to better meet the needs of travellers and to provide the best guarantee of continuing passenger services. Even so, my colleague the minister for transport has announced the government's intention to consider other options for the services, if AN's passenger business is not sold.

The government has already provided $5.1 million for passenger concessions in the 1997-98 budget as well as similar allocations being provided in the forward estimates for this purpose. Paragraph 10 would remove the exemption from the legislative instruments act 1997. In other words, it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. On the chair's advice, I did not move amendment 10, which I am moving separately.
—It is to be put separately.
—I thought you had spoken to it and I was going to speak to it but neither of us were going to vote on it other than separately.
—It can be debated now. I understood that you actually raised it when you made your comments before.
—In the second reading debate, yes.
—I am happy to do it later.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose schedule 4, item 4. The bill attempts to exempt the sale process from the proposed legislative instruments act 1997, which is still in the form of a bill and is currently in the Senate awaiting debate. Exempting it from this future act means the directions issued by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) in relation to the sale process will not be disallowable by parliament. We believe this is unacceptable. We believe it is the duty of the parliament to take a close interest in the sale process. Therefore, we oppose schedule 4, item 4.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate the government's attitude. My advice is that the commercial agreements could consist of one particular agreement or could be constituted by a series of agreements. To allow the parliament the ability to disallow parts of a negotiated commercial agreement would obviously not only jeopardise the ultimate negotiations but would also send shivers down the spines of all those who might already have been minded to put in their applications. In those circumstances, we could not conceive how you could arrive at a binding settlement or agreement without running the risk of it being fundamentally altered by the parliament. In those circumstances, the game would not be worth the candle.
—The question is that schedule 4, item 4, stand as printed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Alston) proposed:
That the report of the committee be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "and that there be laid on the table by the last day of sitting in June 1998 a document which sets out an integrated land transport strategy for Australia, the preparation of which, in the Senate's opinion, should include a process of public consultation".

This is one of the most important amendments we have dealt with today, because one of the strongest criticisms we have of the government's approach to rail is that they have failed to develop and put before parliament and the people of Australia an integrated land transport strategy.

We deliberately use the words `land transport strategy' because you cannot in a country of this size, with the diverse and sophisticated economy that it has, consider road and rail separately. They need to be considered together. They need to be considered in terms of their pricing, access, their taxation regime, integration, competition principles and many other considerations. It is for that reason that the Australian Democrats believe there should be an obligation on this government to put before the parliament and the people of Australia their view, their vision and their plans for a land transport regime in Australia.

It is our further view that that should include a process of public consultation. I have listened with great interest to many of the things that Senator Bob Collins has said in a number of committees over time about transport. I am of the opinion, having listened to arguments such as he puts and arguments such as we and the Greens put, that you would have strong cross-party support for a full consultation process to arrive at a land transport strategy which would do Australia proud as it goes into the 21st century. Accordingly, I commend my amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As much as I can understand what Senator Murray would like to accomplish, and that is presumably to have the Commonwealth give its vision of the approach that itself and others might adopt, the fact is that it would be well beyond the scope of any bill in relation to the national rail system to require the Commonwealth, presumably on behalf of the states which have the principal responsibility for land transport, to somehow map out a comprehensive land transport strategy. It is quite clear that that would be beyond not only the—
—We know it's a dry gulch in so far as you are concerned, Minister.

—It is not just a matter of my enthusiasm for the project. It is a matter of it being beyond the competence of the Commonwealth government to lay down a strategy, the responsibility for which primarily resides with the states. In other words, apart from having some sort of wish document—
—No enthusiasm, no strategy, no vision. He summed it up well.
—I am glad we are agreed. The fact is that the states would be the ones that you should direct this to. If you want them to somehow spell out—
—You are acting legal, Richard. Put some dynamic punch into it.

—Some blokes wander in at the last minute after, presumably, a decent evening's meal and think that they can expedite the process by trying to stir people up. I can assure you that it does not work. Senator Watson did his best to speed matters up by telling us how important it was.

SPEECH.PARA: So all I can say is this is breathtaking in its vision, and I commend you for that, Senator Murray. Beyond that, all I can say is that we have to deal with the areas of our responsibilities. To somehow think that we could usurp the role and vision of the states and set out some document which would have any meaningfulness, I think, just makes it clear that this could never achieve any useful purpose and should, therefore, be opposed.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we commence debate on the appropriations legislation. It is traditional that the debate on appropriations deals with wide‐ranging matters that senators deem important, arising particularly from the budget strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I indicate that the Labor opposition in the Senate will be moving a second reading amendment that will contain a number of points. It will go to the issue of the 1997 budget and its doing nothing for jobs, which is currently the nation's most overwhelmingly important economic and social problem. The second aspect of the resolution will go to the squandering of a significant opportunity for this country to introduce a reasonable level of superannuation retirement savings, which was promised by Labor and also promised by the government, and which this government has failed to deliver.

Thirdly, the resolution will go to the continuing assault on families, the elderly and the needy. Fourthly, the resolution will draw attention to the mindless and counterproductive cuts affecting the quality and decency of life in Australia and harming our international reputation. Fifthly, it will deal with the cuts and their destructive impact, which do not meet the exaggerated expectations that the government has created in respect of the size of its deficit reduction and its projected future surpluses. Sixthly, it will deal with the general overall lack of shape, direction and vision in this year's budget.

I want firstly to make some comments in respect of unemployment and the lack of any significant focus on the creation of jobs in this last budget. What was immediately apparent from the budget speech was that unemployment rated only one mention. In contrast, if we read the section devoted to primary industry, we find that quarantine, which I would be the first to acknowledge is an important issue, rated five mentions. Unem ployment rated one and that really did put into perspective the overall approach of this government to unemployment, job creation, industry policy and to various important regional initiatives that should be contained in a budget if we are to do anything about the increasing unemployment levels in this country. I know that was the first big failure in respect of this budget.

The second issue is the one of private saving and retirement incomes. The approach taken in this budget, as I have already mentioned, failed to deliver on the commitment of the government to 15 per cent contributions into superannuation, into retirement incomes. There are some important economic aspects related to this, which include a consequent increase in private saving, reducing our dependence on foreign investment and our ability to buy back the farm. The third theme, which is touched on in our second reading amendment, is that this budget does nothing for struggling families. In fact, in many areas it makes the plight of low income earners and the elderly particularly worse.

The Treasurer, Mr Costello, predicted last year that he would bring the unemployment rate down to 8¼ per cent. Instead, it has risen to 8¾ per cent and it is still going higher—it was 8¾ per cent at the time of the budget. We have nearly 250,000 people in Australia who are now unemployed for the long term. The economic growth forecast for the next year, despite the pick‐up in the world economy, is projected to come in at just 3¾ per cent. That is still under the four‐plus per cent which Mr Howard and every other leading economic commentator accepts is necessary for unemployment reduction.

Another 16,500 Public Service jobs are likely to go in the coming year. As I referred to earlier, there are no job creation schemes worth the name, no restoration of the labour market programs which were savaged last year and which are so crucial for job readiness and skills training, no regional programs worth having and, just for good measure, a further squeeze on export promotion spending.

I would like to turn in some detail to the issue of the so‐called `savings initiative' announced in the budget, and some issues related to budget announcements on superannuation. Firstly, it is important in this context to draw to the attention of the Senate a problem that Australia shares with the rest of the world. An interesting report—an ABS survey of family trends in Australia—was released last Friday, I think it was. Amongst a range of significant social and economic statistical data, the report confirms the ageing of the population. I suppose it is obvious to all of us that we are getting older. As I look around the chamber the reaction of some of my colleagues makes that more than obvious.

There is a deep‐seated concern and fear in the Australian community, and quite rightly so, about the ageing of our population and the consequences that will flow. I drew attention earlier to the ABS family data that was released last Friday. In 1986 just over 10 per cent of the population was over the age of 65—1.7 million people. In 1996 it was 12 per cent—2.3 million people—over the age of 65. It is projected that in the year 2021 17½ per cent of the population will be over the age of 65. That is just over four million people. By the year 2051—even beyond my life expectancy—23 per cent, six million people, will be over the age of 65.

Australia shares this trend with the rest of the world, albeit our population is not ageing as rapidly as the population in the rest of the world for a number of reasons, including the fact that we have had a significant migration program. This government's approach in that area will be interesting to see. It can only have one effect and that is a more rapid ageing of the population over the next 50 years.

One of the central failings in the budget was the failure to deliver on the committed retirement savings that were promised by Labor, and also by Mr Costello on a number of occasions prior to the last election and even prior to the delivery of this budget. In fact, he committed himself to the extent of delivering the financial commitment to retirement savings in the 1996 forward estimates.

What did we get? Instead of the 15 per cent contribution, the government co‐contribution on top of the superannuation guarantee, what did we get? We had a repackaging of at least part of the funding that was supposed to be delivered into Australian workers' retirement incomes. It was repackaged in the form of a savings initiative that Mr Costello promised during the 1996 election campaign would `knock your socks off'. They were his words to describe what he intended to do with this savings initiative. The Treasurer has delivered on their savings policy that was announced in the election platform and funded it by failing to deliver at all on the three and three, known as the co‐contribution payments to Australian workers' superannuation. He has taken the money from that area, moved it over to a so‐called `savings rebate initiative' and for good measure thrown $1 billion of the money into a Federation Fund, a slush fund to celebrate Australia's Federation.

Labor is not against celebrating the federation of this country; it is a historically important event for this country. But is it worth $1 billion? Is it worth $1 billion effectively transferred out of Australian workers' retirement income? That again highlights the priorities of the government—failing to deliver to Australia's retirement incomes but delivering into a $1 billion fund to celebrate the centenary of this nation. When we look at the ageing population and the worrying economic and social problems that are going to result as a consequence of this, I know where Labor would much rather spend its money and that is in taking care of that significant economic and social problem and certainly not putting $1 billion into a federation slush fund.

The savings rebate initiative really knocked everyone's socks off because it disappeared almost overnight as far as the economic commentators were concerned, and deservedly so. In fact, I well recall the words of former Senator Stone, a former head of the Treasury. I did not have the `good fortune' to be in the Senate when he was a senator but I note that he commented that this savings initiative was bordering on irresponsible. It has been universally criticised—and quite rightly—by a range of Australian commentators. In fact, it was hard to find one economic expert who had a good word to say about the so‐called savings initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the debate on the appropriation bills I want to speak on the issue of process—a subject that is of absolute importance to the fairness with which this society is conducted, to the justice that is administered, to the way our laws are made and to the wellbeing of society as a whole. The board of a private company, for example, must go through proper process to see that the shareholders are properly dealt with. You, Mr Acting Deputy President Chapman, as chair of a very important committee that deals with corporations in this place, would know the importance of this process to the proper administration of any company.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal first of all with the process that goes on within parliament itself. One of the great problems we face as a parliament is that the executive has ascendancy over the parliamentary process, which is not good. I want to deal with that. I think there is insufficient protest on the part of parliamentarians to stand up to executive power. I mention in that context that Senator O'Chee, the chair of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, is in the house. He has the conviction and the courage that enables him and his committee, which is a very good committee, to stand up to the excessive use of power by the executive.

It does not matter what party is in power, the same problem will be there. The task of ministers remains much the same no matter what their political colour. Whether the person who is leading a department is from the ranks of the coalition or the Labor Party, he or she must see to its good administration and the same sorts of pressures are brought to bear on him or her. Often during estimates a minister, no matter from what party he or she comes, will say, `The particular party you belong to, Mr Questioner,'—Miss Questioner, Mrs Questioner or Ms Questioner—`did much the same sort of thing or something worse.' That does not seem to me to be a proper answer to the proposition that has been put. Ministerial problems ought to be teased out. There is executive power that must be restrained. They are the issues, not what colour party the questioner is from.

As I understand it, the Baxter report has been accepted by the government. That report contains recommendations which will affect the departments that directly affect us as senators and our colleagues in the House of Representatives. There is no need for me to go into this in any detail because everybody here knows about it. There are now five departments. As far as we can understand, there is a suggestion that they be rationalised, which is the word that is used these days to indicate that there are going to be changes and that things are to be brought down to lower levels, at least in terms of numbers.

What concerns me is that, as far as I know—and I stand to be corrected—the President, the Speaker and the clerks do not know what those recommendations are. I do not know and, as far as I understand it, no parliamentarian knows what is in those recommendations. It seems to me extraordinary that a plan, a report, a program should be discussed and perhaps agreed upon without any effective input from the people it is going to affect.

The real problem in this case is that it is parliament that will be affected. The parliament is the one body in Australia that is elected by all people of voting age. It is the one body that everybody in Australia votes for. They do not vote for the government. They vote for the members of parliament. Depending on the combination of numbers that are so returned, the executive is elected. In some cases, members of the executive are elected by members of that parliament and in others they are appointed by the Prime Minister.

It seems extraordinary that a body like the parliament should not be master of its own destiny. That is a very worrying feature in this regard. It is the driving force for seeing that proper process is administered and the running of the country and the government is properly checked. It seems to me quite extraordinary that the executive, the creation of this elected body, this parliament, should dictate to the parliament what should go on.

The symbolism of that is very bad. It bears out the sort of thing that Justice Brennan, Chief Justice of the High Court, said when he was a justice of the High Court. When he delivered a lecture to the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory on 7 August 1990 he said the following:

The theory of responsible government which made the fate of an Executive Government dependent upon the confidence of the Parliament was, so to speak, turned on its head by the political dependence of the majority members of the Parliament on the Executive Government. Policy formulation became primarily an executive function. As the pressure on legislative time intensified, a virtual monopoly over initiatives for legislation passed to the Executive Government. The influence of Ministers in debate, whether in the party room or in Parliament, was enhanced by the support they could command from the public service. These developments virtually destroyed the Diceyan theory.
A little later His Honour said:

As the wind of political expediency now chills Parliament's willingness to impose checks on the Executive and the Executive now has a large measure of control over legislation, the courts alone retain their original function of standing between government and the governed.

That is what happens when parliament does not exert the sort of force that it should. The parliament takes it up and then you get the unfortunate situation that you now have when people criticise the courts and, in my view, quite unfairly take the High Court to task. The High Court must carry out its function. That function is made much more difficult because the parliament does not exert itself as it should. Here is the latest example where you have a suggestion that the support that is to be given to parliament is to be arranged in a way that is to be decided by government without, it seems, any effective input from the parliament.

Even if the departments running the parliament were not running well, that would be bad enough. But when you look at the outstanding service that is given in this place by a variety of departments—including Hansard, who makes sense of what is otherwise a fairly doubtful system of English expression that a lot of us use in this place, and the people who give us security and attend upon our needs—it is even more amazing that we should be in a position to give away that ability to control our own destiny. If the administration of those services that are needed to make this place run properly are put outside of it, then we lose control. The immediacy of service is what is needed and what we should insist upon having.

We are paid well. When I say `well' I mean that we are paid well in every sense—we get generous allowances. But we are also paid by people who are attendant to our needs, who make sure things are kept in order and happen on time. People who run the committees are quite outstanding, and so it goes on. In the context of the appropriation debates, I would like to emphasise the need for us, as parliamentarians, to keep control of our services and at the same time pay tribute to the very good services we have.

Our problem is the fact that we are in parties. That is only proper and right. I think Edmund Burke said that if you were not a party person you did not have any proper political beliefs. That may well be so, but I think running parallel to that, in any event, is the proposition that if it is proper and if it is right that we operate as a parliament then we should fill that demand. I think there are ways in which that can be done. As I said, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is one example of that and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is another. It is something that we ought to have regard to. William Blackstone, when he was writing on the English constitution in 1765, had this to say:

It is highly necessary for preserving the balance of the constitution, that the executive power be a branch, though not the whole of the legislative. The total union of them, we have seen, would be productive of tyranny; the total disjunction of them, for the present, would in the end produce the same effects, by causing that union against which it seems to provide.

He was saying that there is a proper place for the executive and a proper place for the parliament and the balance between the two should be attended to. I am not sure whether that it is being attended to at the moment.

I wish to read a quotation from the judgment of Pearse v. Pearse. That explains it much better than I can. This sets out the sort of philosophy that is contained in cases like Ridgeway, which we have dealt with in this place. The judgment states:

The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise than advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against the solicitor, who, in the cause between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton, had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon though it right to prohibit. Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much.
That is certainly a most eloquent description of what process, in this case in terms of the law, is all about.

The fact that a judicial tribunal in proper accordance with the law allowed or disallowed certain evidence does not go to the issue of whether he is a good or bad judge. The issue is whether or not he applied the law correctly—and, in this case, Mr Justice Vincent certainly did that—and upheld in the highest tradition that great philosophy of the law which has served us so well in this country and which served England—the place we got it from—so well before that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to advise the Senate of a journey made by the Prime Minister, John Howard, yesterday to an air base in the north of England. I am delighted, and members opposite should also be delighted, that his itinerary included an inspection of the British Aerospace facility at Warton RAF Base in Lancashire. This is also great news for the opposition because it means that an area of Australia that has had a depressed industrial economy, particularly because your government could never deliver any defence contracts—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think you should be laughing over there given your government's record on defence contracts. I would like to point out that fact—that the previous government did not deliver, Senator Bishop, on this matter. The Prime Minister, John Howard, has now finalised negotiations on the lead‐in fighter contract with British Aerospace. This was widely reported not only in England but also in Australia. That is considerably important because the people in the Labor Party in our area have been talking down the region for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I was delighted tonight to see on the ABC news a five‐minute feature of this particular proposal. The feature showed the Prime Minister in the base in the north of England. It showed models of what was going to be built in Newcastle. It showed—and this is the important thing that has happened this week—that the Prime Minister has finalised this contract and the contract is now ready to sign. Up to the present, the contract going ahead was subject to signing. As we know, in any commercial arrangement, it is not until you get people signing on the bottom line that it is secured. The project could have been lost at any point in time up to now to the Hunter Valley.

The Prime Minister has sealed the deal in the north of England. This is something which Labor, throughout its 13 years of government, was totally unable to achieve for the Hunter. Throughout the 80s and 90s we were constantly let down, usually due to Labor deals with different states. There was a need to prop up the Bannon government in Adelaide, so the submarines went to Adelaide. There was a need to prop up the Kirner government in Victoria, so the Anzac frigates went to Victoria.

Under Labor, Newcastle could not even take a trick with a smaller operation, like the marine sea safety centre. Under Labor, that was lost to, of all places, Canberra, which is over 100 kilometres from the sea. We have a sea safety centre on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin; one would have thought coastal Australia would have been a more appropriate location. I am delighted to inform the Senate that this Liberal government, due to the efforts of a number of people, including my colleague Bob Baldwin, MHR for Paterson, has been able to deliver on this project, whereas previous ALP members in the area, like Peter Morris and Bob Brown, have failed dismally.

I want to outline some aspects of this very vital defence contract that is coming to the Hunter. The Minister for Defence, Ian McLachlan, and British Aerospace officials will tomorrow sign the contract for the lead‐in fighter project. Thirty‐three Hawk 100 lead‐in fighter training aircraft will be provided under this contract, and they will be replacing the ageing Italian Macchi trainer fleet. This new fleet of lead‐in fighters will commence service in the year 2000, and they will have a service operation life of 25 years.

This is great news also for the Hunter, because the maintenance projects will take place over those 25 years in the Hunter. There will be work on construction commencing in September 1998; there will be $850 million spent on the project; there will be 130 workers employed during the construction phase of the project; and there will be 150 people employed during the building of this series of planes in the Hunter Valley. The majority of the planes—21 of the 33—will be built in the Hunter Valley.

This project is coming on line at a time when BHP is starting to phase down in the area. The phase-down over 1998-99 will be replaced with a number of things. Already Warwick Parer has been to the Hunter and announced the coal projects that are about to come on stream in the next two years. Now this week under this government we find further good news for the Hunter, as this government signs this contract and brings the region even more work.

The important thing about this type of work is: it helps to build a new base for the Hunter Valley. We have been a coal and steel based economy. What has happened now with a number of projects is that we are starting to move towards the aerospace industry and have in train a number of high-tech defence contracts, the lead‐in fighter project being the latest.

Mr Maurie Rudd, who is the leader of the AWU in Newcastle, says that there are many BHP workers who will have the skills to take up these jobs, particularly in the construction phase. Also, my colleague Senator Amanda Vanstone was in Newcastle two weeks ago announcing retraining money for industries to take up from BHP people who have certain metal and technical skills and convert them into employees for other industries that are successful in the Hunter at this stage. This sort of project could be extended to include people for retraining out of BHP into work in high tech defence industries.

There will be ongoing employment from this work over a period of 25 years. The announcements made by the Prime Minister in the UK will have a very positive effect on the Hunter. The Prime Minister has put the area of Newcastle and the Hunter on the world stage as a region capable of doing vital defence contract work. The PM has virtually shouted from the rooftops that the area of Newcastle and the Hunter is being repositioned as a hub and centre for high-tech defence industry. Above all, the PM has responded to the closure by late 1999 of BHP in Newcastle with some real projects that will take the region forward.

This decision is a cornerstone of the commitment of actually repositioning the Hunter economy. To the people of the region, it looks and sounds more credible than Labor's rear‐vision approach and demands that BHP stay in the steel industry. The ALP's approach to this matter, I feel, has been absolutely disgraceful; it has been backward‐looking. It has not been useful for the city, and it has not helped develop the image of the city.

But what this government is doing is positioning the Hunter to move forward to the next era of industrial development, which is in defence and high-tech industries. I commend the government for this decision. It is endorsing the Hunter as a very vital part of Australia's industrial infrastructure in regional Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to speak about the issue of women's health. We on this side of politics are very concerned about the fact that the national women's health program is being systematically dismantled. This is of great concern to women throughout Australia. But tonight, I want to focus on another issue. It is an issue often avoided by many parliamentarians—particularly, I have to say, male parliamentarians. So I am hoping the four male parliamentarians who are at present in the chamber will listen very fairly carefully to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue relates to a headline in today's Courier‐Mail entitled `Horan welcomes abortion clampdown plan'. I am referring to the Queensland health minister, Mike Horan. Surely only a male minister could make such a statement. I would like to go through some of the things he has said. The article states:

Health Minister Mike Horan yesterday said he hoped the number of abortions performed in Queensland would be "dramatically reduced" and abortion clinics shut down through a Federal Government committee proposal.
I do not know how he expects to do this when he is not prepared to put funding into sex education, or family planning, or children by choice. The article continues:
Mr Horan said the proposal that abortions be performed only in public and private hospitals could lead to abortions becoming "a rarity" and stop Queensland laws being flouted.

Again, I do not know whom Mr Horan talks to. It is well known, and a recent National Health and Medical Research Council report revealed, that one in four Australian women face an unwanted pregnancy at some stage in their reproductive lives. That is a fact, and I do not know how Mr Horan thinks he can dismiss this reality. The article further states:
Mr Horan said he would establish a ministerial advisory committee comprising medical specialists and administrators to consider the federal report.
There is no mention of consumers, no mention of women; just medical specialists and administrators. I would have thought he might consult with consumers. The article further states:
"If the federal proposal leads to a system where abortion, in the overwhelming majority of cases, stops, we are interested," he said.

It is all very well in politics to make grand statements that you think a section of the electorate may agree with. I respect that there are many people in the electorate who do not agree with abortion. That is their choice and their right to have that view. I respect that view.

I equally respect the view of those women who, when faced with an unwanted pregnancy, choose the option of termination. Women, in consultation with their partners, in consultation with their doctors, should have that right to choose. Every opinion poll conducted in the last 10 years or so has shown an increasing number of people—men and women, rural and city voters—who believe that this is the case. It is similar to the debate we had in relation to another sensitive issue about differences in opinion relating to euthanasia.

The question of women's right to have access to safe termination of pregnancy is one that I feel very strongly about. Many years ago in Tasmania a friend of mine only had access to a backyard abortion and that ended with tragic results. She was never able to bear children. Another case at the same time was that of a young woman who tragically died. I do not want to see my daughters or anybody else's daughters go through the experience of being forced to go to unsafe, unhygienic backyard abortionists.

Here we have a minister who is responsible for health. Let us face it: women's reproduction is a health issue. It is not a question of moralising. It is a question of personal choice and a question of each individual being free to make those decisions in a safe, hygienic environment. I respect the right of people who have different views from my own to have their choice. It is important that they equally respect those women who have a different attitude to termination of pregnancy to have that choice.

I pay tribute to Minister Newman, who has made her views very clear on this subject. I praised her privately at the time, and I now publicly praise her for her stance in relation to women's rights in this matter. I think the time is coming when women in this place and women around Australia will have to say some fairly straightforward things to some men in the community and some men both in this chamber and the other chamber.

I would ask men who are uncertain about debating the termination of pregnancy to ask themselves two questions. First of all: how many unwanted pregnancies have I personally been responsible for? I do not want to know the answer to that question. That is a personal question for men. I would not dream of asking them that question because it is a personal matter. It is in the private domain. Before male parliamentarians in this place presume to make decisions for women, they should ask themselves that question.

The second question I think they should ask themselves is: how many women in my family, how many of my staff, how many of my friends, my constituents and my colleagues have had to face an unwanted pregnancy in the last six months, 12 months, five years or 10 years?

This is a normal part of living for one in four women throughout Australia. It is time we stopped moralising about a matter that is facing women and their partners and their families and their doctors every day of the week.

Yet, whenever you try to talk about women's reproductive rights, women's access to reasonable and safe health services in regard to termination of pregnancy, if that is their choice, I am afraid too many men in parliaments—and, let us face it, there is still an overwhelming monopoly of decision making by men throughout Australia and, indeed, throughout the world—say, `Oh, no, I don't want to talk about abortion. Oh, no, I don't approve.' If they don't approve, if that is part of their religious belief, that is entirely their choice. But I ask those two questions not to be cheeky, not to be rude, not to try to put any individual on the spot, but simply to say that unplanned pregnancy is a fact of life. Men and women have a responsibility in this regard, and too often it has been the women who have had to cope with unwanted pregnancy.
So I hope that Minister Horan will follow the advice of Deputy Leader Joan Sheldon. She has made an excellent statement today, and I commend her for that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an article that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser , my home town paper, on Saturday, which was written by Mr Phillip Coorey. His article was about Dr Robert Weber, formerly the chief executive of the multifunction polis's Australia-Asia business consortium. In relation to Mr Weber, the journalist said:

SPEECH.PARA: The highest paid public servant in South Australia—who received almost $1 million in salary and benefits from the multifunction polis in less than three years—has quit and left the country.

The consortium is estimated to have cost South Australian taxpayers millions of dollars. This is no small amount of money and would have funded, and still could fund, significant and much needed projects directed at research and development relevant to South Australian business and industry. In fact, the report of the Bureau of Industry Economics on the future of the MFP recommended that further funding to the MFP site be terminated. Perhaps this offers us one way of ameliorating to some degree the plight that higher education and research institutions are in at the moment; that is, if we were to redirect some of that funding where it is badly needed.

The multifunction polis was an idea hatched in 1987 by the Japanese government with the assistance of former Senator John Button. The previous Labor government cut funding to universities and to research institutions, such as CSIRO and various universities, yet vigorously promoted the MFP as the leader in the development of international science and technology. From the very beginning, that particular proposal was criticised by the Australian Democrats as well as a number of key and leading academics. One of the principal grounds for that criticism was that the MFP was using resources that should have been spent on both basic and applied research within Australian universities and other research institutes.

From the very beginning, in many respects the MFP was a fairyland, and any suggestion to this effect to government ministers at the time by the Australian Democrats and others was met with derision. The former government, in fact, maintained at the beginning that no government funding would be spent on the MFP. It was to be privately driven. But, for 10 years now, both the federal government and the South Australian governments have poured money into what can only be described as a face-saving exercise.

In the early years, the federal government maintained that the MFP would be the largest development ever undertaken in this country and that, by concentrating resources into the MFP, this facility would stimulate Australian industry and the economy. At that time, I might add, many coalition senators thought the MFP was a mirage. Unfortunately, they did not support the attempts by my predecessor, Senator John Coulter, when he moved amendments in appropriation debates back in November 1991; that is, that the roughly $4 million allocated by the government in that budget to the MFP be removed. His motion was not supported by the opposition at the time.

BREAK.PARA: In the original MFP document, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry included a proposal to build a 2.1‐kilometre high mountain with a runway for launching linear rocket vehicles into orbit. Both federal and state governments, including the South Australian government, have spent considerable sums trying to convince the public that the always ill-defined MFP was a profitable and productive way to spend the public's taxes. In fact, I recall that it held a number of expensive conferences, costing something like $1,000 for two days. That was on one particular occasion.

The former Bannon government in South Australia spent $150,000 on a public relations firm to convince South Australians and other taxpayers of the particular worth of the MFP. It employed several chief executive officers, and now the latest million-dollar man has quit without achieving his stated goals, leaving behind a program which spent $2.2 million of taxpayers' money in 1994-95 and 1995-96.

Last year's achievements were a tour of Malaysia, which failed to sign up any businesses, and an intention to join two university business schools and do some planning. So it is really remarkable now how unwilling governments, politicians and many bureaucrats are to admit that they have made a mistake and how a lot of public money has, in fact, been spent on defending the indefensible.

In the last few years, two projects have been promoted as the achievements of the multifunction polis: the cleaning up of the polluted Gillman site and the building of a group of energy efficient and novel energy technology‐using houses in North Haven. The Gillman site was a success, but it did not require the expensive backing of the MFP. This site is now suitable only as a sink for northern Adelaide's storm waters. Several university departments, together with soil engineers and a few earth movers, would have had the same effect and, of course, much more cheaply.

As for the two houses in North Haven, they are not a serious attempt to address the urgent need to develop more energy efficient housing for Australian conditions. Firstly, the houses were not built by the MFP but by a private builder. Not one has eaves to protect the walls from heat gain or loss, and solar water heating is absent.

One house has a geothermal heating and cooling system that circulates water through a deep pipe underground and, inside the house, uses this constant‐temperature water as a heat sink for a reverse cycle refrigeration system to heat and cool the house. This system is unusual in Australia and may not hold promise of more energy‐ and cost‐efficient housing. To find out, it would be necessary to monitor over a year or more every aspect of the energetics and economics of the system. But no monitoring equipment has been fitted into this unit and there has been no analysis of energy saving. This is simply window‐dressing for the uninformed and the uninitiated.

Given the report by the Bureau of Industry Economics recommending that funding to the MFP be terminated, the failure of the MFP to deliver any of its promised benefits and the considerable employment cost with no identifiable benefits, it is time in light of all these concerns for the government to realise the mistakes that have been made—in part by its predecessor, and I do acknowledge that—and to divert any funding that might otherwise go or have gone to the MFP to our universities and to institutions such as the CSIRO. These are the organisations that can deliver on the research and development necessary for the future wellbeing of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to revisit the Australian National University student association election fraud that occurred in late 1996.
—You're joking!
—Order! Senator Conroy, interjections are unruly. They are even worse when you are out of your seat.

—Madam Deputy President, I can understand the concern of the Labor Party because their people were directly implicated and involved in this matter and, when they hear the contribution I am making this evening, they will see that the suspicions previously stated now appear to have been confirmed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised this matter on two previous occasions, on 3 October 1996 and on 5 February this year. In my contribution on 5 February this year, I made the suggestion that it would be appropriate for handwriting experts to be called in to determine the link between certain individuals' handwriting and ascertain who in fact was responsible for what has now been determined an attempted fraud of the ballot.

Those who have followed this saga would be aware that 146 ballot papers were spirited into the ballot box without having been appropriately cast by individual students. The attempt to put the wad of ballot papers into the ballot box was found out, and the scandal has now been referred to as `Wadgate' because of the wad of ballot papers that were found. The papers were all neatly folded together in one big wad, and when the ballot box was opened it was found that the ballot papers were still together so they were able to be quarantined from all the other votes that were cast.

In doing so, they were able to be kept and my suggestion of 5 February this year has now been taken up. I have been advised that handwriting experts were called in and that a positive identification has now been made, according to my source, with a Mr Daniel Jenkins the person who was found to have committed the fraud in any event. I understand that this is a huge development in this case. I understand from my source that the testing has been done by an eyesight test and also by pressure tests, and that the conclusion of the experts is that it is a very distinct handwriting and there is nothing to convince them that it is not different from the person who was suspected.

I can indicate that this handwriting analysis was not undertaken as part of a police investigation. However, having said that, I know that the ACT Attorney‐General has written to the Australian Federal Police asking them to inquire into this matter. I understand that in recent times the Australian Federal Police have accepted the suggestion and will now be undertaking their own investigations into this fraud.

I raise these matters in the context of the people and persons involved, and it is quite clear that all 146 of these ballots were cast for the Labor Party candidate for the post of president of the student association. It appears that at least some others were involved but who we are not sure of. Nevertheless, it was designed to gain an election result and to pervert the course of democracy. Of the people involved in this, I note that Mr Jenkins rejoices in the title of vice‐president of the Labor Club on the ANU campus. So, despite having been found to have committed this fraud on his fellow students, he remains as vice‐president of the Labor Club and was being promoted as such on campus during the orientation week early this year.

It is this same group of students that is now trying to promote the affiliation of the ANU with the National Union of Students. I simply want to say this evening to the students at the ANU, `Be very careful of those people promoting affiliation with the National Union of Students.' When you consider the lengths to which they are prepared to go to effect a local student election result, one wonders what they would be prepared to do to gain effective control of the National Union of Students, which undoubtedly is an organisation that plays on a bigger stage, has more money, has more power and would be seen as an even greater stepping stone for those seeking to embark upon a political career. I would say to the students at the ANU that they would be well served by remaining out of the National Union of Students. Indeed, a former National Union of Students executive member, Mr Brad Woods, said on 8 August 1992 that:
. . . NUS has an appalling history of fraud and failure. It has funded left wing extremist causes and violent demonstrations.

The Australian Higher Education Supplement of 10 January 1996 told us that the ALP, and the unity faction in particular, dominated the NUS. Mr Jenkins, as I understand, is a member of the ALP unity faction. So it appears that since Mr Woods made his comments in 1992 not much has changed within the political culture of those who support the National Union of Students and who are seeking to have the student body at the Australian National University affiliated with the National Union of Students.

It is to be hoped that this matter will proceed further, with the ALP taking some responsibility in seeking to discipline Mr Jenkins, and also that the university administration will take the matter further. It seems unfortunate that the university has not been prepared to involve itself to the extent that it should. I compliment those who were involved in having the ballot papers analysed with another sample of handwriting to ascertain the author of the signatures on the back of the ballot papers.

It really is a very sad and sorry reflection on elements within the student movement at the ANU that, first, they engage in this sort of behaviour and, second, that the person involved in that sort of behaviour is allowed to continue as a vice‐president of the Labor club on campus and that that same organisation is shamelessly now promoting the National Union of Students on campus as the way to go for students. It is quite obvious that the motivation of these individuals is shamelessly selfish; that they want to gain their political careers and gain access to the bigger student stage—but, of course, at student expense. Their motivation has been exposed by their involvement in this fraud and their inability or unwillingness to take any suitable and appropriate action to deal with that fraud.

I am pleased this evening to be able to indicate that my suggestion of handwriting analysis has been taken up and that the results that I have indicated tonight have come forward. I am also pleased to have been told that the Australian Federal Police are investigating the matter. The only thing that remains to be said is that the students at the Australian National University would be very well served to steer clear of the National Union of Students, especially those elements promoting affiliation, who have been involved in such scandalous conduct.
